title: needle free coronavirus jab trial end pandemics
story: Experts at Cambridge University have developed a vaccine for Covid- that would be administered to people through the skin via a jet of air.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHuman trials are set to start in the autumn and the government will fund the first human trial to the tune of £. million.The vaccine is being developed by DIOSynVax, a company founded by Professor Jonathan Heeney, who is the head of viral zoonotics at Cambridge University, along with University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust.He said the goal is to “make a coronavirus vaccine that will protect us not only from this pandemic, but the next one”.The vaccine will use a device which is already used for some cancer treatments.Experts say that pushing skin cells using air can induce finely tuned responses in comparison to other vaccines.Most vaccines that are currently being developed work by exposing people to a “spike protein” which the virus uses to connect with human cells.In order to develop the new vaccine the team at Cambridge analysed hundreds of coronaviruses - including those found in bats.They then used their results to build a library of antigens which mimic the molecules on coronaviruses.The experts say that the aim of this is to find shared antigens between dferent coronavirus, which could mean that one jab could protect against all of them.Prof Heeney said: “We’re looking for crucial pieces of the virus that we can use to direct the immune response in the right direction. Ultimately we aim to make a vaccine that will not only protect from Sars-CoV-, but other related coronaviruses that may spill over from animals to humans.”  He added that manufacturing of the vaccine should be cheap and said that it does not need to be refrigerated.This means that the vaccine will also be accessible to people in hotter countries.Prof Heeney said it’s unlikely that the new vaccine will trigger a bad immune response.The first trials will take place at the National Institute for Health Research Southampton Clinical Research Facility at University Hospital Southampton.Director of the facility, Professor Saul Faust said: “It is critical that dferent vaccine technologies are tested as at this stage no one can be sure which type of vaccine will produce the best and most long-lived immune responses.”It comes just days after Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty said he would be surpriseda vaccine was available before .The daily increase in fatalities and cases across the UK has continued to slow this month however health authorities are on high alert for any spike in the deadly bug.Prof Whitty today said he would be delighteda vaccine came early.But the CMO said: I’d be quite surprisedwe had a highly effective vaccine ready for mass use in a large percentage of the population before the end of winter, certainly before this side of Christmas.”He added: I think it is unlikely we will have a vaccine that is highly effective and ready to deploy at scale this winter meaning  .I think there is a reasonable chance that we will have vaccines, not a certainty, in the period before the following winter of  .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lockdown free brazilian city herd immunity coronavirus
story: Manaus, in the Amazon, has seen a dramatic fall in coronavirus cases and deaths since hitting , fatalities.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe city of two million people was once one of the worlds hardest-hit, with drone images taken in April showing mass graves and burials occurring at five times their normal rate. But last week, Manaus saw its “excess deaths” drop to almost zero - as tests suggested that around  per cent of the city’s population had been infected with the bug. Jarbas Barbosa da Silva, assistant director of the Pan American Health Organisation, told The Washington Post: “The hypothesis — and this is just a hypothesis — is that the peak we had in Manaus was very strong, and there was such widespread community transmission that it may have produced some kind of collective immunity”.Mr Barbosa said that the fall in cases suggested a “natural dynamic”, rather than the effect of lockdown or other preventative measures. However, it is not confirmed whether the fall in cases and deaths could also be due to underreporting in the area.Herd immunity refers to a population’s resistance to the spread of a contagious disease built up through immunity from infection or vaccination.Sweden controversially opted against a lockdown in favour of a herd immunity policy set out by state epidemiologist Anders Tegnell. But the policy proved controversial, leading to the worlds sixth highest per capita death rate - with care homes hit particularly badly.New research, reported by The Times, showed that levels of combined T-cell and antibody immunity could be more than  per cent. Dr Tegnell insists that this level of immunity makes it easier to control the outbreaks than when there is no immunity at all among the population.Scientists assumed, at the beginning of the pandemic, that around  per cent of people would need to be infected for the disease to fade away. But Henrique dos Santos Pereira, a scientist at the Federal University of Amazonas, said there was no “concrete explanation” for the mysterious drop in cases in Manaus.Brazil, meanwhile, has suffered one of the worst outbreaks in the world, with ,, cases and over , deaths. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories wore frank spencer benny crossroads
story: A magnicent record to behold. I cannot remember any government being so devoid of direction, leadership, policy, conviction and — frankly — intelligence.And I had to endure Ted Heath AND John Major’s attempts to run the country. Oh, and the shaft of glorious sunshine that was Gordon Brown. Those guys have nothing on Boris. He is the clear leader in the field. If you ever wanted to know what a country would look likeit was led by Frank Spencer, here you go. Yes, I know — I’m showing my age. To be honest, under this administration I’m feeling my age.For those who don’t remember, Frank was a bumbling, dithering, halfwit from the s sitcom Some Mothers Do ’Ave ’Em. The only dference with Bojo is that Frank was thinner. And, mercully, a fictional creation. Boris is all too real. Many kids will be going back to school wearing face masks. For ages, this government insisted that they would not have to do so. Now they’ve changed their minds. Face masks and grouped in “bubbles”. Probably getting only about half of their usual education,that. Any kid who coughs will be pounced upon, exiled to the Outer Hebrides and the entire school shuts down. Never mind that there has been no recorded case of a schoolkid passing on the virus to a teacher.Never mind that our economy needs the schools fully open with a proper, normal, timetable, so people can get back to work.After six months of no lessons , the kids now have to endure insufferable conditions at school.This is because Boris and the rest have proved utterly incapable of standing up to the teaching unions .Other U-turns have involved the wearing of masks in shops, the usefulness of masks in general, whether there’s any point in closing our borders, the schools due to re-open in June, the scrapping of an expensive track and trace system, the re-grading of GCSEs and A levels . . . oh lordy, the list goes on and on.Sometimes the U-turn appears only a day after the original decision.Sometimes we have to wait a week or so. But come they surely do, a long parade of staggering ineptitude. In fact, I think even Frank Spencer would have been more decisive. Maybe the right comparison is with Benny from Crossroads. Yes, it’s my age again. For those who don’t know, Benny was a cast-iron moron.We know that dealing with this horrible pandemic can’t have been easy. We know Boris has had a dficult year.But the utter lack of planning and resolve has been astonishing. Slow to take the virus seriously, bizarrely refusing to close our airports at the peak of the outbreak, hopelessly lost over track and trace and what do with our poor kids.This has been mismanagement on an almost heroic level. My guess is that Boris will not survive as Prime Minister: His party will get shot of him when the opportunity arises. Because here’s the crucial, damaging question.Could Jeremy Corbyn have handled this crisis any worse I DON’T think those smug monkeys at the BBC realised the fury they would unleash when they banned singing our favourite anthems at The Last Night Of The Proms.A petition reached , names in just  hours.And Dame Vera Lynn is suddenly at No in the iTunes chart with Land Of Hope And Glory.The BBC apparently agreed with the Finnish conductor, Dalia Stasevska, that the “jingoistic” words of Land Of Hope And Glory and Rule Britannia would not be heard this year.I wonder what convinced Ms Stasevska to agree to conduct an evening of patriotic songs when she hates patriotic songs Money, you would guess. Meanwhile another BBC bureaucrat, Cat Lewis, likened singing the songs to Nazis singing about gas chambers.Silly woman. The BBC – its entire staff – has no understanding of the British people. It despises them. Support for the corporation is at an all-time low. And yet the BBC is still up to its tricks. Pulling off the unusual feat of being already in a coffin, but reaching out somehow to hammer more nails into its own lid.A TEAM of British scientists has been studying dreams and what they mean.And they’ve discovered they mean sod all. They are just a continuation of memories from the previous day.Other recent studies showed the same thing. So,you dream you’re flying around your house with some bats, it means you were probably thinking about bats when you were awake.It doesn’t mean you’re neurotic or sexually repressed. So – that’s all the work of Sigmund Freud in the bin. It can go in a black bin liner along with the idiocies put forward by that other drongo of the th Century, Karl Marx. But given that we know all this, why are there still psychoanalysts plying their trade  Is it just to give Britain’s couch-makers plenty of work ANOTHER stupid, virtue-signalling British firm has run into trouble.Avanti West Coast made a big fuss about its new “pride train”, which runs from London to Manchester.The engine is painted in the colours of the LGBT rainbow flag.And it has the word “Pride” written in big letters – just in case anyone doesn’t get the message. There have been thousands of angry comments on social media.My favourite was from John James McGivern: “As a gay man, I don’t want a ‘pride train’, I just want to get on a train that runs on time like everyone .” Quite. Well said.Every time companies pull a stunt like this, the nation cringes.I don’t want a bloody voucher. You cancel the train I’m booked on, then refund the ticket.So I complain to them and they say nothing we can do.So I complain some more and tell them they’re acting illegally.Bingo – money back! I know a lot of people have had similar problems with airlines cancelling their flights and offering “vouchers”.It pays to pester these buggers. Pester and pester until they give in.POOR old slabhead, then. Manchester United’s Harry Maguire found himself uttering the most stupid words in the English language.“Do you know who I am ” And then explained to the Greek police officers who had arrested him that he was “very rich”. Then he tried to bribe them.⚠️Click here for the latest news on Harry MaguireGod help us all.I have always admired Maguire’s heading ability.It now seems to me that he gets so much force behind each header because he has reinforced concrete between his ears. Footballers are not renowned for being terribly bright.But Maguire has lowered the bar still further.One of the problems is the one to which the footballer alluded. He has too much money. So much that he doesn’t know what to do with it.And as a result is completely insulated from the real world. And when he does venture out into the real world it is to be continually abused by halfwits who do not like the club he plays for.Say sorry to the Greeks, Harry. And then shut up and play football.Andlouts give you abuse in the street, just smile at them.CHILDREN from working families were much better behaved during lockdown, according to a study from three British universities.I know that will come as news to some of you.A lot of kids seemed to be climbing the walls out of sheer boredom. But the researchers found that the kids had fewer tantrums. And their concentration improved, too.Maybe we should have a lockdown every year.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ex education chiefs call to reopen schools
story: Tories Damian Hinds, Justine Greening and Kenneth Baker, Labour’s David Blunkett and Lib Dem David Laws all united.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey told The Sun there is a “desperate need” to reopen schools and they warned: “The future of our country depends on it.” Any longer out of the classroom risks causing untold damage to kids’ studies, health and wellbeing, they added.Together, their time in charge of England’s schools spanned four decades.Ex-Education Secretary Lord Blunkett, , said: “Getting schools reopened is absolutely fundamental to everything that we stand for.“We send children to school for a purpose — and that is because their very future and the future of our ­country depends on it.”The country’s schools, colleges and nurseries closed for most kids in March as coronavirus swept the country.The national schools shutdown was the first in English history and a string of alarming reports found it has ­massively widened the education gap between rich and poor. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has promised to get all of England’s pupils back to class full- time next week.The ex-schools supremos warned that No cannot fail in this test.Lord Baker,  — who was Education Secretary under Margaret Thatcher — said that the Covid education crisis could be as bad as the recession.He said: “This is the Prime Minister’s biggest challenge now, getting all children back to school.“You will find that some parents are anxious, and that some children won’t want to go back — but we have got to get them into the routine of schools.“Once you lose out on a stage of your schooling like this, you may end up losing out for ever.“It affects a child’s entire future. It is very, very important and it must happen.” Ms Greening, , who was Education Secretary under Theresa May, said the past six months have been “hugely damaging” for kids.She said: “Parents have done their level best home-schooling but we urgently need schools open safely so children can get back to full-time education. We also need a catch-up plan to help them recover lost ground.”Mr Hinds, , Education Secretary until July last year, said: “Kids desperately need to get back to school.“In the immediate term, mental and physical health are supported by the routine of going to school, interacting with friends and teachers and accessing purposeful activity.”Mr Laws, , Schools Minister during the Coalition, said: “Given the huge learning loss during lockdown, particularly for the poorest children, it’s vital we do everything we can to ensure a fullto school next week, provided this is supported by the health advice.”It is a crucial test for Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, who is clinging on to his job by a thread in the wake of humiliating U-turns on mask wearing in schools and A-level results.Fuming Tory MPs have urged No to sack himhe fails to get schools reopened on time.Perhaps an adult wearing a mask in a lab makes them safer but I believe children in a school will be less safe with masks. Do we really imagine a world where our teenagers turn up every day to school with a freshly washed mask which they will wear without issue throughout the day  They will swap their masks, ping them, lick them, spit in them and pass them around for fun. They will shout obscenities through them, bully each other over not having the right type, wear them wrong and they will encourage them to touch their faces dozens of times a day.And teachers need to be able to see the mouths of their charges to hold them to account for chatting, swearing and the like. Mask them up and teachers won’t have a clue who said it. Eventually you have chaos in the classroom. Hand-washing, social-distancing as much as one can and keeping children in bubbles is the way to go. Headteachers should not be swayed by how things appear and rather look seriously at how things really are.Schools in Wales are also reopening next week, while they have been open for a fortnight already in Scotland.All of the UK’s chief medical officers have declared that it is safe for children toto school.On a visit to a school in Leicestershire today, Mr Johnson said: “This is an absolutely invaluable time for them — they must get back into school.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour mp tory brexiteers last night of the proms
story: Neil Coyle wrote the late night potty mouthed tweet in reply to one by Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg, in which he expressed his support for Boris Johnson’s criticism of the BBC.It came after organisers of the BBC Proms said Land of Hope and Glory and Rule Britannia! would be featured as orchestral versions instead.This was reportedly due to concerns about the offensive connotations contained in the songs about the British Empire.The ensuing row prompted the PM to criticise the BBC’s “wetness, a view warmly endorsed by Mr Rees-Mogg who said: “Britons must never be enslaved by political correctness.”That appeared to infuriate Mr Coyle who tweeted: “I have spent years warning local people that these fat old racists wont stop blaming the EU when their s*** hits the fan.“Here they come blaming others. Absolute s***bag racist w*****s.”He also responded to a video of Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage singing Rule Britannia, saying: “If you didnt hate it before, feel free to hate the song now.“Ive never known anyone but sh**lickers like it tbh [to be honest]. In response the Labour Party said the Proms were “staple of the British summer” and enjoying patriotic songs “was not a barrier to examining our past and learning lessons from it”. A petition to restore the lyrics of Rule Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory at the BBC Proms smashed , signatures in just two days.During a visit to a Devon shipyard, Mr Johnson weighed into the row.“I think its time we stopped our cringing embarrassment about our history, about our traditions, and about our culture, and we stopped this general fight of self-recrimination and wetness, he said.I wanted to get that off my chest.In a bid to defuse the row, BBC bosses announced last night that the Last Night on September  would still feature familiar, patriotic elements.It said: With much reduced musical forces and no live audience, the Proms will curate a concert that includes familiar, patriotic elements such as Jerusalem and the National Anthem, and bring in new moments capturing the mood of this unique time [...].It added that the programme will include new orchestral versions of Pomp and Circumstance March No  Land of Hope and Gloryand Rule Britannia.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: newlywed honeymoon sunburn thick cloud second degree
story: Shocking pictures show the extent of the second-degree burns Nicola Law endured, and now the -year-old is warning others of the potential dangers of sunburn even in overcast weather. Nicola hadnt worn cream due to the grey clouds while sitting on the top deck of her cruise ship, but the shins on both her legs burst into blistering burns.The -year-old claims the pain was the worst shes ever experienced - even though shes been through two hip replacements and childbirth.The new bride had left suncream in her bag in the cabin after heavy cloud cover and choppy winds cancelled the cruises exertions in the Bahamas, West Indies, for the day.Nicola and husband Stephen Law sat on the top deck chatting with pals without sun cream on - with the mum-of-ones celtic complexion leaving her vulnerable to sun damage.When Nicola woke up the following morning, she immediately collapsed after getting out of bed as shooting pains made her knees buckle and left her in the worst pain ever.Enormous blisters erupted over both her shins which were so big the outlines were visible through her jeans.The terried mum was forced to burst the blisters before walking through airport security for fear that security guards would pull her to one side to find out what she had in her trousers.The wounds produced so much liquid that Nicolas shoes were squelching and she was making puddles so had to buy sanitary pads to soak up the moisture during the six-hour flight.She was in so much agony she needed a wheelchair to get through Dublin airport once she landed.But the complacent mum still dismissed it as regular sunburn - until Stephen, , was urged by a pharmacist to take his we to AE immediately.Now Nicola is speaking out about her ordeal to warn others to take proper precautions in the sun - and to not underestimate sun damage through the clouds.Nicola, from Lisburn, Northern Ireland, said: Ive had two full hip replacements and given birth naturally, and the pain from this was  times worse than any of them. Ive never known pain like it. It was so intense.Ive been sunburned loads of times because I fry dead easily. Usually I do the aftersun and usual moaning and groaning and tell myself off for being stupid. But never has it been that bad.My husband had to help me stand up to go to the toilet or anything. Once I was moving I was okay but standing up when the pain went right up your leg, I buckled a few times because it was that bad.The blisters got so big that you could see the outline of them through my trousers.By this stage I just wanted to go home and I was afraid of the airport security either thinking I was hiding something or not letting me fly.I burst the blisters, which I found out afterwards was the worst thing I couldve done. The liquid that poured out of me, my shoes were squelching. I was leaving puddles when I was walking.I ended up going into a shop in the airport and buying a pack of sanitary towels and a pair of long socks and putting the sanitary towels inside the socks to catch the fluid from my legs.That flight was the longest, most intense flight of my le. It was terrible. We were cramped in one place and my legs were just throbbing.I had to be wheelchaired off the plane to the front of the airport to get my lt because by this point I couldnt physically walk.Doctors diagnosed Nicola with second-degree burns and even contemplated using skin grafts to repair the damage.But luckily, after four days in the burns unit and doctors cleaning and changing her wounds daily, she was allowed tohome on March   without surgical intervention.Nicola claims she has kept her legs covered up ever since and applies factor  sun cream as often as she can - but still feels guilty for ruining the end of her honeymoon.Nicola said: The consultant asked me how long I had been in the sun and he said he couldnt believe how much damage I had done in such a short space of time.He wouldve thought that I had fallen asleep in it or been out in it for hours. He said it was because I was on the top deck so I was closer to the sun.We were out at sea so we had the salty air and the breeze coming at you as well. He said thats actually worse than being in the glaring sun. I didnt know that at the time. I thought because it was cloudy [I would be fine].I knew once I was on the beach I would need the sunscreen, but because the weather was so bad and it was so cloudy and windy, I thought I dont need it yet so I will put it on later as it warms up.It was ignorance and stupidity on my part. story: But what is citriodiol, and what is it used for Citriodiol is a natural insect repellent and is derived from the oil of the Eucalyptus citriodora tree - commonly known as the lemon eucalyptus.The substance smells similar to menthol and has been used in insect repellents since the s.The organic, colourless compound is the active ingredient in repellents like Mosi-guard, which costs about £ for a ml bottle.The natural chemical is used to deter insects and mosquitos from biting and irritating your skin.Jacqueline Watson, the Managing Director of Citrefine, said: We are very excited by these findings and have several new studies either already going through laboratories or planned.Scientists at the Ministry of Defence have been testing Mosi-guard, a Citriodiol-based spray, on plastic and articial skin at the Defence Science and Technology Lab in Porton Down, Wiltshire.The spray has been given to Army members since April, as it has been known to kill other strains of coronavirus.Jeremy Quin, a junior defence minister, said the research found that sprays containing Citriodiol “can kill the virus”.But the scientists warn: “We have no data relating the concentration applied experimentally to the latex to that resulting from a spray and rub application of Mosi-guard on human skin.”The research however did show that Citriodiol does have anti-viral properties. After an hour there was “some loss of recoverable virus” on the latex surface.The DSTL has published its initial findings to help others conduct further research. title: brexit update binned germany
story: The regular meetings usually have their agendas decided weeks in advance, but theres been a last-ditch change after the latest rounds of talks ended yet again in deadlock.An EU diplomat told the : Since there hasn’t been any tangible progress in EU-UK negotiations, the Brexit item was taken off the agenda.It comes as Germany is said to be growing more and more frustrated with the lack of progress between both sides.Shes understood to have shut the door on further discussions on Breixt for now until theres any real signs of a breakthrough.One source said: It all now hinges on October.Another added: We have had the whole summer completely wasted.Both sides are still stuck over issues of fishing rights - and whether Britain will stick by EU laws after we leave infor access to the continents market.Michel Barnier last week blasted the Brits for wasting time in the discussions.This week The Sun revealed how Barnier has knocked back Britains new blueprint for a trade deal and urged EU capitals to remain cold blooded as the Brexit deadline looms.Brussels negotiators have told other EU states that the draft text for an free trade agreement tabled by the UK last week is unrealistic and not a basis for discussion.British officials had expressed hopes the new text would inject a bit of spark into the stalled talks.But EU sources said the UK seems to be negotiating on game theory rather than substance.Mr Barnier is now braced for a major bust up with No  next month with fears of a bitter no deal Brexit growing in Brussels.In a gloomy briefing to diplomats his team warned last weeks tetchy round of talks only made things worse between the two sides.An EU source told The Sun: Outsiders don’t realise how pessimistic we’ve become.We expect the mood to switch rapidly to contingency planning, in expectation the UK will throw itself into the blame game rather than the end game.Boris Johnson originally said he wanted a deal on the cards by the end of the summer - but the deadline has now been pushed back into September.British negotiators still think a deal can be done.Meanwhile the EUs Mr Barnier has stressed talks cant go on past the end of October.Hes more pessimistic, saying a deal is now unlikely as the two sides fail to resolve their dferences.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ed davey liberal democrat leader
story: He beat challenger Layla Moran with , votes - double the amount she managed to get.Speaking today, the MP for Kingston and Surbiton said his party needed to face the facts that the Lib Dems have had three disappointing general elections where they failed to win over the nation.And the truth was that they were out of touch with the rest of the country - a far cry from the power they held in coalition government with the Conservatives from  - .Voters have been sending us a message, but we have not been listening, he said today.I have got that message, I am listening now, he told the nation.He insisted his challenger Ms Moran would have a key role in rebuilding the party.Sir Ed - a former pork pie maker - was at the announcement in central London today with his we Emily.He told his party faithful: I’m determined our party backs a Britain that works with other countries across the world for peace and prosperity. But it is my love of our party that makes me recognise that we have to change.The Lib Dems have now had five leaders in the last five years.Sir Ed played an important role in the Conservative-led government under David Cameron and became energy and climate change secretary in .In  he was defeated in his Kingston and Surbiton seat after  years as an MP, but won it back from the Conservatives in .He has ruled out any future coalition with Jeremy Corbyn or Boris Johnson and has described a no-deal Brexit as a nuclear option.If that did come to pass, Sir Ed said he would push for the Lib Dems to form a temporary government with other parties.He said: That would just be a temporary government for one purpose and one purpose alone - to pass the legislation for a peoples vote.In June Sir Ed was criticised by his leadership rival after he suggested his electoral strategy could decapitate that blonde head of Mr Johnson.After the criticism, Davey tweeted he regretted the use of violent language.He has also revealed worked in a pork pie factory and Boots as a teenager.The Lib Dem leadership kicked off after Jo Swinson quit following the  election - but had been postponed because of the ongoing coronavirus crisis.Sh lost her seat to the SNP during a terrible election night for the party where they ended up with just  seats - one fewer than before.They ran on a huge Stop Brexit message which flopped and failed to even win over Remainers.The latest polls show the Lib Dems currently running at a dismal  per cent.Its a far cry from their golden days of  - where the their challenger party ad a whopping  seats.Sir Ed was always the bookies favourite to win the yellow crown this time around but hes still an outsider at   to become PM, they said today.Alex Apati of Ladbrokes said: Ed Davey always looked like winning the Lib Dem leadership race as far as the odds were concerned but its unlikely well be seeing him challenge the likes of Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak for PM.It comes after The Sun revealed Ms Moran once said kids should get the vote.The lefty loudmouth said she thinks kids should be able to vote when they “feel ready”.The Oxford West MP admitted her call for votes for young kids is a “crazy idea”.Quizzed on her views on votes for  year-olds at a fringe political event, she backed lowering the voting age.She added: “I’m going to lob a crazy idea, and see where it goes - Why   I met some really, really on-point ,  and  year-olds. My personal view is that you should be able to vote when you feel ready.”Tory MP Maria Caulfield blasted the barmy comments. She said: “We knew things were bad for the Lib Dems, but offering to give primary school kids the vote is desperation. They’ll be offering free Fortnite tokens next.”Ms Moran said the comments, made at the party’s conference in , no longer reflect her views.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionFool Britannia: were a land of dopes and Tories, and its about time we stopped singing about itIf youre angry about song lyrics, then you arent paying attention says Fleet Street FoxShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  AUG Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. This shouldnapost be necessary to say, because we all had history lessons and we were awake for some of them. But Britannia has never ruled the waves.We had officially-approved pirates who stole gold from the Spanish and started the slave trade. We had glorious navies that had a habit of sinking, we dodged U-boats, we provided the first circumnavigation of the globe, and the first man to do it alone. But we also had a king who told the waves to go away, and collective amnesia about the point he was trying to make.King Cnut did not get his feet wet in the th century just so he could be a cipher for a swearword on Twitter , years later. He tried to rule the waves in order to prove that, despite being a warrior king with  North Sea countries beneath his heel, waves do their own thing. Britannia was around before him, was revived as a bit of Elizabethan militarist propaganda, and in  got nicked by a prince who wanted a song to impress his dad, George II. At the time, our ruling of the waves was centred on what became known as the War of Jenkinsapos Ear, about slave trading rights. We lost. The Prime Minister, who likes to give the impression he knows more history than anyone , must know that Rule Britannia is a silly song. He must, surely, realise that these islands did not pop up from an azure main, has noangels, and especially that not only has it got one of the smallest navies of all time, but is about to have a cavalry without any tanks.He probably does think, as verse  does, that foreign nations must, in their turn, to tyrants fall, that we are the envy of them all and our cities shall with commerce shine as verse  proclaims. But itaposs bollocks. Mainly because anything you tell George II in  to keep him happy is bound to be, but also because Boris Johnson has put this country on a course to - let me just check this official government document - ah yes, complete economic and social meltdown. That is no reason for the PM not to make a fuss about the BBC being too wet to let us sing a jaunty tune. Because otherwise we might notice that Dominic Cummings has given £m in uncontested government contracts to his mates, that a misogynist Aussie with no business experience has been put in charge of our Brexit trade deals, and that heaposs u-turned so often the PM is technically doing doughnuts in Downing Street. Of all the things that should be making anyone, of any political bent or age or race, steaming mad today, the fact that an empty Albert Hall will not be shaken to the rafters by , people who only know the chorus anyway is the very least of them.Get angry about Cummings gting a total of £m in contracts to colleagues and friends to find out what the public think of the government, when he could ask his neighbours for free.Fret, why donapost you, about how a shadowy group of Right-wing conspiracy theorists who claim to be protecting children marched on Buckingham Palace to shout paedophile! at Prince Andrew, despite the fact not a single Royal was in residence and the crimes he is accused of, while heinous, do not include paedophilia. Such stupidity is expected, by Brits, in other countries - itaposs pretty worrying to see it manest in The Mall.Or you could be infuriated by shame at the country being run by people who genuinely believe the Board of Trade should be graced by a man of without business experience, but who sent refugee children to sicken and starve on a Pacic island and whose reputation, such as it is, was savaged in the most devastating political speech Australia has ever witnessed.  Second thoughts, letaposs not. Merely boiling with fury does not seem to change much. If it did, Piers Morgan would be God.Letaposs ask ourselves, instead, whether to mask, or not to mask that is the question. Whether apostis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of these absolute cockwhistles, or to take arms against a sea of troublesome twits, and by opposing, end them.Letaposs remind ourselves that weaposre arguing about masks only because incompetents who have spent decades arguing about bendy bananas and how many children theyaposre responsible for are now in charge of keeping us safe, and are arguing about that, too. The question to ask is whether you put up with all this, or arm yourself with the knowledge and facts they would rather you didnapost have. Like the background to Rule Britannia, the lyrics you never knew, and wondering how it is that this country has forgotten it started, and ended, slavery fought just, and unjust, wars honoured, and destroyed, countless wrongaposuns. History will tell you that Britain is not all bad, and not all good. Richard the Lionheart was a magnicent warrior, and brutal Islamophobe and anti-Semite. Elizabeth I was feted as a great beauty, and ended her days a crone with blackened teeth. Queen Victoria was thick as mince, Bazalgetteaposs sewer and WT Steadaposs th century sensationalist journalism did more to improve public health than any -word slogans, and our last  Prime Ministers have been an ever-decreasing circle of ineptitude who have deprived this nation of everything it still had that was great. Common sense went out the window with austerity. Historical perspective, the ability to see the past and future and our place in it, was pissed up the wall in the Brexit referendum. And irony, Iaposm afraid, is sobbing quietly in a little ball under Nicola Sturgeonaposs Holyrood throne, from whence she is ruling the entire United Kingdom. All outrage aside,there is something that has been a constant in the UK down the centuries it is a substantial majority of people who look at those strutting about the national stage and ignore them. Itaposs how the monarchy, and any number of governments, has survived.

story: NewsMasks in schools - the new rules on where and when children need to wear face coveringsAfter another spectacular U-turn, the government has decided that some children can and should wear masks and face coverings in school. Heres the new rules and who they apply toShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG News " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Government performed another spectacular and humiliating U-turn last night, this time on children wearing masks or face coverings in English schools. Ministers had insisted there would be no recommendation for children to wear face coverings in communal areas, and said the scientic evidence backed them up. But late last night, after the Scottish Government had issued obligatory guidance that pupils should wear face coverings when moving around schools from Monday, the Department for Education issued a change in advice. But what are the new rules  When and where will children have to wear masks - and will it apply to all schools  Hereaposs everything you need to know about the new changes. What measures are being introduced in England  From September , and in secondary schools in England that are within areas under local restrictions, face coverings should be worn when moving around corridors and communal spaces. This does not include classrooms and does not apply to primary-aged pupils. Why are face coverings not required in classrooms   Guidance from the Department for Educationsays that it will not usually be necessary in classrooms, as protective measures mean the risks are lower - such as grouping staff and students in bubbles. Face coverings can have a negative impact on learning and teaching and so their use in lessons should be avoided, it adds.So in which areas should face coverings be worn in secondary schools  Additional precautionary measures apply to places defined as areas of national Government intervention, as listed on the gov.uk website, according to the guidance. Local restrictions are currently in place in areas of Greater Manchester, Lancashire, and West Yorkshire, Leicester, Luton and Northampton. Can schools recommend face coveringsthey are where in England  Schools and colleges outside of local lockdown areas will have the discretion to require face coverings in communal areas where social distancing cannot be safely managed, the guidance says. It gives the example of a school or college which has a layout that makes it particularly dficult for people to stay apart. Are there any exemptions  Yes. Those who cannot put on, wear or remove a face covering because of a physical or mental illness or impairment, or disability, will be exempt. Guidance says that exemptions also apply to people who provide assistance to someone who relies on lip-reading, clear sound or facial expression to communicate. Could the measures be changed further  Education Secretary Gavin Williamson ruled out the requirements for face coverings in Englandaposs schools being extended further. When askedthe measures could be extended, he told the BBC: No, no, thereaposs no intention of extending it beyond that because as bothsaid andsaid is that actually that isnapost what is required. What has the Scottish Government announced on face coverings  Face coverings should be worn by staff and pupils when moving around secondary schools in Scotland from August , according to Holyroodaposs Education Secretary. John Swinney said that the rule will apply on school transport for primary school pupils aged five and above, and all those at secondary school in communal areas, but not in classrooms.

Publication of that figure came at the height of the Brexit referendum campaign and was seized on by anti-EU activists as evidence that Britain had “lost control of its borders” because the UK was unable to stop EU nationals coming because of freedom of movement rules. The latest figures show , people moved to the UK compared with about , who left. The increase in immigration and net migration was fuelled by an increase in Chinese and Indian students coming to study in the UK, analysts said. Jay Lindop, director of the ONSaposs Centre for International Migration, said: “Our best estimate of net migration, using all available data sources, is , for the year ending March . This was being driven by increases in non-EU student arrivals, mainly from China and India.  The IPS data were collected up to March  and do not take into account the signicant impact the pandemic has had on international migration since then. Migration Watch UK chairman Alp Mehmet said: The latest net migration figures from the ONS are shocking,not surprising. “The record level of net non-EU migration is an indication of the scale of the problem and what the Government needs to control and reduce. “The proposed points-based system will do nothing of the sortanything, the inflow of migrants from around the world will increase. story: NewsInside home of Britains worst hoarder with mummied rats and piles of rubbishSpecialist cleaners had to be called to the home of Paul, , because the mountains of rubbish and collections had reached the ceiling. His kitchen and bathroom had be unusable for yearsShareCommentsByJenny Kirkham:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsMummied rats were found inside the home of Britains worst hoarder" %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailShocking pictures show inside the home of Britainaposs biggest hoarder where mummied rats were found. The house, belonging to -year-old Paul, had to be cleaned by specialists after piles of rubbish and mountains of collections reached the ceiling. His bathroom and kitchen had been completely unusable for years but Paul said he got around this by eating outside, going to cafes and going where to have a shower. Paul and his mother bought the three bedroom house in Crosby, Merseyside,  years ago, after his father died, for £,. On Channel  documentary Hoarders, which airs on Thursday night, he said: We had a nice modern kitchen, nice garden as well, it was a very attractive house.  But hoarding is often triggered by traumatic le events and the problems in Paulaposs home began after the said death of his mum, Liverpool Echo reports.He said: Four and a half years after my mother died, in , thataposs when I started collecting. I think in the back of my mind, I thought aposthat will look nice in the houseapos a bit like what my mother had. And then it began to overwhelm me over time and got too much. The books are the first thing that started to pile up and Iaposve got a couple thousands books now. During the programme, George Mensah of Merseyside House Clearance was called in to clear Paulaposs home.  Unable to even enter the property, George was forced to climb over the mounds of belongings that Paul had accumulated and even used a special camera to be able to see further into the home. During his survey, the master cleaner found rats that had become trapped in the house and then died, being left to rot and stfen amongst the rubbish. Some of the most commonly hoarded items, such as papers, books and clothing, were all found in the rooms of the house as George made his way through. This had filled up every room in Paulaposs house, including the hallway, but some other items that Paul had collected were slightly more unusual. Roman artefacts, weapons and armour were also discovered during the clear out. One bedroom was the only area of the house that George could properly access. Paul hoped that cleaners could sht his hoard for him and he would be able to sell the home, which lies on a quiet street in Sefton, to fund his retirement. During the clean up process, Paul found it dficult to let some of his items go and could be heard telling Georgeaposs colleagues not to throw books away and saying he wanted to keep a part of the Roman wall in York.  After some of the hoard was cleared, Paul was informed that due to the damage he had caused to his home by the hoarding, it would only be worth £, on the market. It took eight skips and nine days in total to clear Paulaposs house before potential buyers were able to come and view the property. Hoarding disorder is the mental health problem that has led people to leave their homes in filthy conditions, piled high with rubbish and has even led to a number of court cases over the years. The Royal College of Psychiatrists and the NHS have signicant information about hoarding disorder and what it can mean for people day-to-day but also explains that hoarding can lead to signicant problems, such as those above. Here are some of the most common questions about hoarding disorder, what it means, and how to stop it getting out of control. What is hoarding disorder  Hoarding disorder is where someone acquires an excessive number of items and stores them in a chaotic manner. This usually results in unmanageable amounts of clutter and in some cases hoarding in your home. Most common items that people hoard Some people with a hoarding disorder will hoard a range of items, while others may just hoard certain types of objects. Items that are often hoarded include newspapers and magazines, books, clothes, receipts and household supplies. Some people also hoard animals, which they may not be able to look after properly. More recently, hoarding of data has become more common. This is where someone stores huge amounts of electronic data and emails that theyaposre extremely reluctant to delete. Why do people hoard  The reasons why someone begins hoarding are not fully understood but it can often be a symptom of another condition. Mental health problems associated with hoarding include severe depression, psychotic disorders and obsessive compulsive disorder. In some cases, hoarding is a condition in itself and often associated with self-neglect. These people are more likely to live alone, be unmarried, have had a deprived childhood or have a family history of hoarding. How can hoarders be treated  Hoarding disorders are challenging to treat because many people who hoard frequently do not see it as a problem, or have little awareness of how itaposs affecting their le or the lives of others. Many do realise they have a problem but are reluctant to seek help because they feel extremely ashamed, humiliated or guilty about it. Itaposs really important to encourage a person who is hoarding to seek help, as their dficulties discarding objects can not only cause loneliness and mental health problems but also pose a health and safety risk. Hoarding makes it dficult for a person to move around their home, and it can also cause their work performance, personal hygiene and relationships to suffer as it takes over their le. So much clutter in a home can be dangerous and unhygienic. It can lead to rodent or insect infestations, be a fire risk and block exits in the event of an emergency, cause trips and falls, or even collapse on peoplekept in tall piles. To help a person with a suspected hoarding disorder, try to persuade them to go with you to see a GP, the NHS says. It adds: This may not be easy, as someone who hoards might not think they need help. Try to be sensitive about the issue and emphasise your concerns for their health and wellbeing. Reassure them that nobody is going to go into their home and throw everything out. Youaposre just going to have a chat with the doctor about their hoarding to see what can be done and what support is available to empower them to begin the process of decluttering. The main treatment is cognitive behavioural therapywith a therapist who will help the person to understand why they are unable to bin things and allow clutter to build up. Antidepressant medicines called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors have also been shown to help some people with hoarding disorders, the NHS says.

I had my surgery the week before the hospital closed for non-essential surgeries. If I hadn’t got it then I would still be ill and virtually housebound so I feel I’ve really been quite lucky and this is just the icing on the cake.

story: NewsNightmare neighbour hounded grieving widow with hate campaign over shrine to late husbandAnthony Kenyon, , claimed the tribute which was placed by Margaret Ilkovics, , in memory of her late husband Richard was a health hazard. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA neighbour from hell hounded a grieving widow after he objected to her setting up a shrine in memory of her late husband in their communal garden.Anthony Kenyon, , subjected church volunteer Margaret Ilkovics, , to a hate campaign after she placed shrubs, ious ornaments and a memory box under a pussy willow tree as a daily reminder of her late spouse Richard who died of cancer aged just , a court heard. Kenyon claimed the tribute at Regina Court in Salford, Greater Manchester was a health and safety hazard and was said to have uprooted the ft high tree, killed off the grass and plants with weedkiller and even damaged the ornaments which included commemorative dolls. He was also accused of writing poison pen notes claiming Mrs Ilkovics had a bogus husband and that she had only married him for his money and suggested she was involved in shoplting.Kenyon would rant and rave at her from behind a window at his flat and unnecessarily summoning ambulances to Mrs Ilkovicsapos home wrongly claiming she had a severe mental illness and needed taking away. During one incident Kenyon dumped some of the ornaments in a shoebox on Mrs Ilkovicaposs wheelie bin whilst she was away on holiday with an acerbic note saying: Please find enclosed the funeral ornaments you placed without permission.Said items Iaposm reliably informed are supposed to be placed indoors either side of an urn for example. Whilst one appreciates certain iniduals placing such items and all manner of other rubbish on graves, It is not acceptable in a domestic garden.You have caused not only an affront to my religious beliefs but blocked access to the fire escape and wasted police time.  Another note he put in his window referred to Mrs Ilkovicaposs home saying: Goods available strictly CODconvicted shoplter. At Manchester magistrates court this week the so-called Battle of Regina Court came to a climax with Kenyon being convicted of harassment between September  and February . He was cleared of assaulting Mrs Ilkovics by throwing a dog toy at her. He denied any wrongdoing. The court heard Mrs Ilkovics had married her husband in June  as he lay terminally ill in hospital and he died the following month.  But she fell out with Kenyon when set up the shrine outside their respective homes in the apartment complex which houses the elderly or those with disabilities. Mrs Ilkovics told JPs: Before Rick got ill we planted a little pussy willow in  and after his death I put a few things that were a tribute to him - plastic hearts, flowers and such like. The little heart had apossadly missedapos on it and there was a little angel and a little heart with flowers that my friend gave me to put there. It was something to put there in honour of my late husband - it wasnapost a great big tribute it was just three little ornaments.  When Mr Kenyon originally moved into his flat I had personally asked him does he mindI worked on the garden and put things in it and his answer was: aposyou can do anything you want with it - Iaposm not into gardening.apos I like a nice garden it is therapeutic for me. But the first thing was I received was note in the box I had made which was saying I only married Rick for his money and that he was a aposbogusapos husband. My sister had invited me over to Portugal for a week but when It got back, a neighbour was at the door waiting for me she said: aposthey are on the bin and I saw a note about the ornaments. I felt very upset as it was about my husband and my husband was my le. What Mr Kenyon was saying about the ornaments was horrible. How can an ornament cause a fire hazard  I reported it to the housing association but I received three more notes saying hateful and nasty things about me having second and third hand stuff in the garden - that I was this, that and the other.  One was pinned to the dolls outside my front door. I had bought some slates as I thought the turf was dying but it was due to weed killer. I had seen him spraying weed killer on the garden on a number of occasions - why should he use weed killer on the garden knowing it would kill my plants that I took pride in  It has affected me a lot. I have depression and anxiety and at one stage I wanted to kill myself. I couldnapost live with the pain of what he was doing to what once was mine and my husbandaposs pride and joy. It hurt a lot losing my husband and it still hurts now. It then really hurts when I look at what this man has done outside my front door. He could have knocked on my door instead of ripping them up and putting them in a black shoe box on top of my bin.  Itaposs disgusting and horrible to have to live with. I lie awake all night thinking he is going to do something and most of the time Iaposm right. He went berserk on everything and he couldnapost have a conversation with you. He would just shout things like aposcan you get rid of those things apos I was told to remove the dolls from the front door they said it was blocking a fire exit. They had been screwed down but they got broken into pieces by Mr Kenyon. There was one left near my bin shed with all horrible stuff tipped on it. On one occasion my friendaposs daughter paid for me to go to Costa Del Sol to get a break. I had not long been back home when I got a knock on my door at am and there was loads of banging outside.  I knew it would be something to do with Anthony Kenyon. I soon found everything smashed up and pulled up again - the trellis with the roses, the rose bush, the trellis around the garden. The fencing all smashed up. The pussy willow had been twisted asit had tried to drag it out and I nearly fainted. I was anxious and upset because that was the last thing that I could remember my husband by. Mr Kenyon was was talking through the window, ranting and raving about my roses on the ground being at his doorstep and using terrible language. I donapost know what he was talking about. He was mentioning Rickaposs name all the time and calling him names. He didnapost even know Rick who was a wonderful man. I have become a hermit in my own home I donapost feel asmy own home is my home anymore. But I wonapost leave as it has got my memories of my husband.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailResidents in a new estate are up in arms after being told they are all about to lose around two metres each of their driveways or gardens after developers forgot to build pavements. Most of the new neighbours on the Maples estate in Holton-le-Clay, Lincolnshire moved in two years ago. Now developers, Snape Properties Limited are getting the road ready for Lincolnshire County Council to adopt and maintain them, including the installation of a two metre path along the road.The homeowners were shocked at the discovery that their land is going to be built over as their gardens and driveways currently go right up to the kerb, reports GrimsbyLive. Robert Stafford, , is one of the residents, who co-owns his property with Lincolnshire Housing Partnership . He said: None of us knew about this. LHP are saying this was in the plans the entire time, but when I was sold the house we were sold it as a two car driveway and a large front garden. The plans that we were shown were also very unclear, it looked like a photocopy of a photocopy, and there was no distinct area between our house and the road. We are all angry because we werenapost told about this when we bought the house. If it was already in place or we were informed from the start that paths would be installed, then fair enough, but we feel like we were mis-sold the house. There was little to no notice about the gardens being torn up, either. We received a letter a few months back saying the roads were going to be made ready for the council to adopt them, but they didnapost say anything about the paths being installed. This has had a big impact on the residents that live there, who have seen their front gardens dug up while they have been out at work. Robert said: A nurse that lives several doors down was almost in tears because she came back from work and found her front garden a mess because they had dug it up. Itaposs upset a lot of people here. My partner stopped them from digging up the land the other day, but it has been marked and we are losing about half of our front garden. Some people own part of their house with LHP, while others own theirs outright, and those that own their house outright are really upset. Iaposve lived here for  months and we are only just finding out about it now.  We got an email from LHP saying itaposs the buildersapos fault for putting down grass right to the road, but they should have told us that we were going to lose that land because of the path either way. title: explained what is classed as an outdoor venue
story: Following the decision a pop-up bar in Aberdeen did not classy as an outside space, we take a look at what does.Shortly before opening yesterday The Draft Project on Langstane Place was told by council officers its venue could not be considered as an outdoor space.What is and isn#t an outdoor space was defined in the Smoking, Health and Social CareAct  and The Prohibition of Smoking in Certain PremisesRegulations .The coronavirus regulations initially based the determination of what should be considered an outdoor space.A premises is considered indoors or #substantially enclosed# :the opening in the premises has an area orthere is more than one, both or all those openings have an aggregate area, which is less than half of the area of the walls, including any other structures serving the purpose of walls, which constitute the perimeter of the premises. This meansarea of the doors and open sides of structure # like a giant marquee # are greater than half of the total area of all the sides, it is considered an outdoor space.However,an open side of the marquee or structure is within .m of a wall, this no longer considered open due to the impact of structure on ventilation.In the case of the Draft Project # which has open sides, it appears council officers have used this description to determine it can not be considered an outdoor space.Outdoor venues are permitted to have up to  people from five households in a group. Indoor venues are only permitted to have eight people from three households in a group. title: new business opportunities to be explored between scotland and guyana
story: Aberdeen and Grampian Chamber of Commerce is to host a free international market briefing in association with its South American counterpart.It is hoped the session, held in partnership with Georgetown Chamber of Commerce, will provide an opportunity to discover more about the new business potential for Scottish energy companies in Guyana.The session will include insights from a range of speakers about the immediate need for businesses in Scotland to partner with indigenous companies.Contributors will include Greg Quinn, British high commissioner to Guyana, Nicholas Deygoo, president of Georgetown Chamber of Commerce and Sherwyn Naughton, country director at the department for international trade.Guyana is in the world’s top  oil reserves and is the second highest in terms of potential among unexplored basins.Questions can be submitted in advance or raised during the session, which takes place on September .There will also be an opportunity to apply to join BB meetings with prospective new partners as part of a virtual trade mission to Guyana later in the month.Companies who are interested in joining can find full details and register their interest at agcc eventsFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t tMonthly n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: study set to begin in bid to save north east hotel

title: union chief calls for more teachers to be hired for aberdeen schools
story: Bosses at a teaching union have called for more teachers to be hired to help city schools cope with the impact of Covid-.The EIS wants the Scottish Government to provide Aberdeen City Council with funding to employ more staff.Leaders at the union say this would allow education officers to make class sizes smaller, enabling physical distancing between pupils.And they also claim teachers would be able to spend longer with each child # helping them catch up after they missed out on several months of classroom learning due to the pandemic.Ron Constable, the secretary of Aberdeen City EIS, said: “We want to see more safety measures put in place for our members. We would say there needs to be a continuing focus on social distancing for kids through smaller classes.“It is possible to have smaller classes but the Scottish Government needs to release more funding. It would also assist children in terms of them catching up, because they have all missed out on so much time in school. Teachers would be able to spend more time with them.“They have got to release money for more teachers to help make classes smaller.#Mr Constable also urged Aberdeen City Council to #go beyond# the Scottish Government#s rules on safety by introducing additional measures.He said: “When the Scottish Government issues advice, we look upon that as the baseline. Local authorities shouldn’t be caught up in just sticking to that – they should be looking at how they can increase that further.“If there are opportunities to stop the transmission of the virus within the local authority, they shouldn’t think they can’t go beyond what the Scottish Government has said. They are able to do that and where they can, they should.“They should be looking at things like whether we should be wearing masks in classrooms, perspex screens and specialist masks for teachers with breathing problems. It’s important councils have an open mind about what can be done on top of the guidance which already exists.”John Wheeler, Aberdeen City Council#s education operational delivery convener, said the local authority was satisfied current safety measures are sufficient.He said: “The national guidance outlines a list of controls that have to be in place and a range of additional controls that can be put in place as an additional precaution.  Schools across the city have worked incredibly hard to put a signicant number of optional controls in place and approaches have been agreed by all staff.#Our data suggests that the controls in place are effective and we continue to monitor things on a daily basis and update approaches in keeping with national advice and local intelligence.#A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government said: “We are already investing £ million to bring additional qualied teachers into classrooms in the new school year, to intensy support for children and young people as theyto full time face-to-face education.“While the recruitment and deployment of teaching staff is a matter for councils, based on their local needs, this funding must be for additional staff on top of the existing teacher workforce and is estimated to be sufficient for local authorities to recruit approximately , people such as post-probationers and recently qualied teachers, as well as any other qualied teachers currently seeking work.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - title: derek mcinnes knows finally reaching europa league group stages could ease financial impact of coronavirus pandemic on aberdeen
story: Boss Derek McInnes believes reaching the Europa League group stages can ease the financial hit of the Covid- pandemic.Aberdeen faced a crippling £ million black hole as a result of the coronavirus outbreak.That predicted shortfall was slashed to £.m due to measures including wage cuts, fresh investment and season ticket sales.Qualying for the promised land of the Europa League groups would secure the Dons £.m in prize money.Each group stage victory then secures £, in prize money with £, for a draw.As well as the financial boost of virtually wiping out the £.m Covid- loss, McInnes has also challenged the Dons to secure some European respect.The first step on the road to that group stage target begins tonight with a first qualying round clash with Runavik at home.McInnes said: “Getting to the group stages would be like winning a trophy.“It gets tougher to get there and more and more obstacles are put in front of teams like ourselves to do it.“But once you get there, the rewards financially are brilliant.“That would be a huge benefit for the club in this current climate.“There is also the respect the club could get from being in the group stages.“There is obviously a trade-off with thatit starts to impact domestically.“You have seen bigger clubs than us struggle to get the balance between dealing with domestic fixtures and group stages.“But for us, getting to the groups would be a brilliant achievement and it’s what we are after as we set off. I’ve spoken to the players about that.‘We know we are not going to win the competition, but we can get to the group stages.“For me, it would feel like a financial win and a win all around. Hopefully we can be that team.”Aberdeen have failed to progress beyond the third qualying round stage in six successive seasons under McInnes.He hopes it will be seventh time lucky in a season in which qualying rounds have been reduced to one leg by Uefa.McInnes is aware the all-or-nothing stature of a single leg makes it more precarious.He said: “If you are the underdog for one game you are underdogs for two games, usually.“With the one-off ties there are fewer minutes to play so for that reason any team who aren’t favourites will have a better chance of going through.‘Whether we are favourites or underdogs, we understand that we have to bring a level of performance that we are happy with.“We’ll give our opponent every respect. Regardless of these early rounds, we’ve always tried to respect our opponent. Any team that beats their opponent - deserves that respect.”Runavik made club history last week by progressing in a European round for the first time.In defeating Barry Town United - in the Faroe Islands, it was the first time in  attempts they had progressed to the next round.In  European matches at preliminary or first qualying round level NSI Runavik have won just three, lost  and drawn two. In , they lost - on aggregate to Hibernian.McInnes said: “I think there is an automatic feeling thatyou have not heard of a team you should be beating them.“Dferent nations are stronger than others, butyou start to look a bit deeper into any opponent you can see there is a calibre of player and performance within each and every team. Runavik are no dferent.“It’s a one-off game. I’ve always felt that ordinarily you need to bring two decent-level performances to get through a tie.“The nature of the competition now means we just need a strong  minutes and hopefully get the job done.”Aberdeen could not send anyone to the Faroe Islands to watch NSI Runavik’s preliminary round due to Covid- travel guidance.McInnes has studied footage of the game, albeit the match was shrouded in heavy fog.Faroe Islands international striker Klaemint Olsen scored a hat-trick. Olsen has scored more than  goals for Runavik.McInnes said: “They’re a very good possession-based team who have good experience and a talismanic striker in Olsen.“We’ve got to make sure we’re good at our own game and bring a level of performance.”Aberdeen have suffered a troubled start to the season with three postponements following coronavirus protocol breaches.The postponements have restricted the Dons to just three Premiership games this season, while, in contrast, Runavik are  games into their league.McInnes said: “We expect a tough match. Their biggest advantage over us is that this is their th game of their season, which started in May.“The benefit of them playing games is that we’ve got to see plenty of them in action. We feel we have a good handle of them.”Aberdeen will hand a late fitness test to Niall McGinn on an ankle injury. Scott McKenna is fit, having been substituted at half-time against Livingston.Funso Ojo is suspended following his red card last season in the - home loss to HNK Rijeka. Craig Bryson , Sam Cosgrove , Mikey Devlinand Ryan Edmondsonare out.McInnes said: “Niall has got a chance. He got a scan on Monday and thankfully it’s nothing sinister.
