title: zans-wildlife-diary-otter-esk
story: Although I love ying the subjects of my photographs and learning about new species as I travel across Scotland, my favourite animal remains the kingfisher at the River Esk at Musselburgh.Very often, when I go on a walk along the river, I chat with other wildle enthusiasts. This is how I heard about an otter at the Esk for the first time three years ago.A few people mentioned they had seen this elusive creature a few years ago, but never since.The otter became my new photography challenge. I tried visiting the river at dferent times of the day, especially at dawn and dusk, when otters are more active, always trying to keep the noise down to a minimum.After two years of searching, my hope was gone and I almost gave up. Until one sunny day in April during lockdownhellipThe weather that day was enjoyable, so Chris and I decided to go on a walk. The local path was very busy the dog walkers, cyclists, families with children and joggers were enjoying the sun whilst social distancing.As always, I kept my eyes low on the water hoping to see the kingfisher.As we followed the river upstream to the area at The Grove, I spotted something moving in the water.I grabbed Chrisrsquo hand and I pulled him down on the ground right behind a bush.It was not a kingfisher but something I did not expect to see in the middle of the day... an otter fishing!We managed to crawl down the slope and lie down so we would not disturbit.Whilst I was photographing the otter, I also heard a cheery pee-pee-pee and saw the kingfisher flying past the otter. What a day!Since then I have seen the otter a couple more times.The Eurasian otter is a secretive, semi-aquatic species with chocolate brown fur, webbed feet, and a powerful tail. Their thick coats are built of two layers of fur: an inner layer that works as insulation, and the outer, waterproof layer. The two-layered system prevents their skin from direct contact with water and subsequent temperature loss.Their nostrils and ears stay closed as otters swim underwater.Despite being excellent swimmers, they cannot hold their breath underwater for long periods the average time underwater is about  seconds as they e.Otters are solitary, territorial animals, that live in underground holes called lsquoholtsrsquo. The size of their territory ies and depends on the quality of the habitat, amount of food and number of possible holts.It is also known that a male otter has a larger territory that can even overlap several female ottersrsquo territories. Otters usually have a well-defined area within their grounds in which they feed, rest and breed.Seeing signs of otters is generally easier than seeing the animals themselves. If you happen to find yourself at the riverbank or a sea loch, look for five-toed footprints and otter droppings , that are left in places such as fallen trees, rocks and weirs.Spraints are easily identiable as they contain visible fish bones and have a characteristic and not particularly unpleasant smell that has been described as ranging from fish to freshly brewed jasmine tea!The otter that you may see at the coast is very often called a lsquosea otterrsquo however, this is the same species as the animals that live further inland.If you would like to share how you get on finding the otters oryou have any rare kind of wildle in your area, I would love to hear from you.Speak to you next month!zanslensfacebook zanslens instagram zans_lens twitter zans_lens

title: retired-musselburgh-nurse-writes-book-caring-people-dementia
story: Dee Jenkins, , of Eskmills Road, said the main aim of the publication ndash I Remember Dementia ndash was to encourage carers of dementia patients.Born in Dublin in , Mrs Jenkins, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, came to Scotland in  to enter a religious order, the Novitiate for the Sisters of La Sagesse, at Leuchie House, North Berwick. When it closed as a convent, the home became available for respite work for multiple sclerosis sufferers.Mrs Jenkins went on to train at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh from  to . She then joined the initial team of nurses at St Columbarsquos Hospice when it opened in .Mrs Jenkins left the order after  years and moved to Wales in  to take up a position as matron in a care home specialising in dementia care.She continued to care for people with dementia after ing to Scotland in , spending a decade in Edinburgh until she retired at the age of .Mrs Jenkins said: ldquoI worked in independent care homes as a manager, with the responsibility of training staff in this specialised field.ldquoI was inspired to write the book because people are becoming more aware of dementia and conscious of the dficulties it involves.ldquoI hope that my experiences might encourage those caring at home and provide some practical help and guidance.She added: ldquoIrsquom aware that Musselburgh as a town has shown a consciousness and willingness to provide supportive groups in this field of care, and hope this book may be of additional help and interest.The book is available on Amazon.

title: giant-crane-vessel-helping-build-neart-na-gaoithe-windfarm
story: Neart na Gaoithewindfarm, which will feature  turbines, is being built  kilometres off the coast of Dunbar.The first phase of construction is getting under way, with a semi-submersible crane vessel, the Saipem S , now in place to start the installation of casings for piles.The S will also work on preparing the seabed in advance of the arrival of the steel foundation jackets on which the  wind turbine generators and two offshore substations will be installed.This giant vessel is nearly  metres long and is designed to be able to work in the most challenging weather conditions.It can carry out heavy lt operations up to , tonnes at sea.Full commissioning of the pound billion windfarm, which will also be visible from North Berwick and is owned by EDF Renewables and ESB, is due to be complete in .Matthias Haag, NnG project director, said: ldquoThe construction phase of the NnG offshore windfarm is now well under way and many people will be able to see the S starting construction work offshore.ldquoIt will be visible from much of the East Neuk of Fe and from North Berwick and Dunbar.ldquoWe have carefully considered the implications of Covid- and Scottish Government guidelines as the work gets under way offshore and for the continuing onshore works.Onshore work continues on the project at ious locations along the cable route, which starts at Thorntonloch beach and finishes in the Lammermuir Hills.

title: hard-work-bringing-dunbar-corn-exchange-back-use-remarkable
story: Dunbarrsquos Christmas lights team has been based in the townrsquos Corn Exchange, off High Street, for a number of years. However, concerns have regularly been raised about the condition of the building, which dates back to .Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, thanked volunteers for the hard work that had gone into ensuring the building did not become further dilapidated.She said: ldquoI was really thrilled to be invited to come and have a look at the Corn Exchange.ldquoIt is remarkable what the team has done there. It was damp, smelly and inhospitable and now it is fully lit, it is dry and it is comfortable.ldquoI think a huge thanks has to go to Graham Adams, Craig Rapson and the Christmas lights team for what they have done.

title: aldi-plans-reverse-vending-machines-north-berwick-tranent-stores
story: The lsquoreverse vending machinersquo would be in the car parks at the retailerrsquos North Berwick and Tranent stores.Plans for the machines are with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A statement included within the planning applications explained the purpose of the devices.It reads: ldquoA reverse vending machine , in its simplest form, is a device that accepts empty beverage containers and s a rewardto the user.ldquoThe user inserts the empty beverage container into the RVM, where it is scanned, identied and determined to be an eligible container.The statement continues: ldquoWhen consumers go into a shop or hospitality business to buy a drink, they will pay a small depositon top of the retail price.ldquoConsumers get their deposit back when theytheir empty plastic bottle, glass bottle or steel aluminium can.ldquoThere are two ways totheir empty containers. These can be ed manually over the counter or by using an automated reverse vending machine that scans the container barcode when they are deposited.If approved, the machines would result in the loss of five parking spaces outside the Tranent store, on Haddington Road, and four spaces at the store on North Berwickrsquos Dunbar Road.Plans for the North Berwick store were discussed at a local community council meeting on August .The community council welcomed the recycling containers but said it would be bestit was open at the same time as the store and restricted to those hours rather than open  hours.Member Peter Hamilton raised concerns neighbours had over potential noise, especiallypeople were putting bottles into the machine late at night.Further planning applications are expected for the supermarket chainrsquos other two county stores in Haddington and Musselburgh.A spokesperson for Aldi said: ldquoAldi is working to prepare for the introduction of the Deposit Return Schemein Scotland in line with the Governmentrsquos introduction date.ldquoThis includes reviewing the physical layout of stores to ensure they meet the requirements of the regulations covering DRS, including the installation of RVM in appropriate areas.

title: partnership-social-isolation-charity-bowling-club-haddington-celebrated
story: Our Community Kitchen and Haddington Bowling Club have been working together for more than two years to tackle social isolation in the town.Volunteers have prepared meals in the bowling clubrsquos clubhouse, on the townrsquos Wemyss Place, before dishing them up to visitors.That has changed during the coronavirus pandemic, with the food being delivered to people throughout the town.The hard work has earned praise from sportscotland, the national agency for sport, and Bowls Scotland.Sarah Pryde-Smith, Bowls Scotland national development manager, said: ldquoWe know how dficult and challenging these past few months have been, but we are heartened to see clubs like Haddington supporting each other and their local communities.ldquoThis partnership approach between Haddington Bowling Club and Our Community Kitchen is an excellent example of why bowling clubs truly are at the heart of the community and we are delighted to see the club being able to provide a much-needed service to the local area.ldquoWe are now in phase three of ourto the green and our clubs have demonstrated resilience, patience and creativity throughout the Covid- pandemic.ldquoWe will continue to work collectively to ensure our wonderful game s stronger than ever.Before the global pandemic, the bowling club ndash which is the oldest in Scotland, dating back to  ndash gave volunteers full use of its facilities three times a week.Up to  people visited each day for a three-course meal and an afternoon chatting with new-found friends.However, with social gatherings banned, the volunteers revamped the model.The charity has  volunteers, who worked four days per week during lockdown, preparing hot meals in the bowling club kitchen to deliver to residentsrsquo homes.They delivered  meals every week.Stewart Harris, chief executive of sportscotland, said: ldquoIt is heartening to see the great work being done in East Lothian, with so many people coming together to help others.Elaine Gale, Our Community Kitchen founder, said: ldquoWe feel our partnership with Haddington Bowling Club is wonderful and unique.ldquoThe committee and members have always been so welcoming, they have helped us raise funds and offered help in plenty of other ways, too.ldquoWe simply could not do what we do without them and I feel this is a perfect opportunity to say a huge thank you to them.ldquoWe have all made new friends through this venture, which canrsquot be underestimated.Colin Dick, club secretary at Haddington Bowling Club, said the club was desperate to help the community in any way it could.He said: ldquoItrsquos a great relationship actually we see ourselves as partners.ldquoWersquove found our members attending the community kitchen during the week.ldquoIt is a balance because we are a bowling club and we have a responsibility to our members but equally we want to try to help our community wherever we can.

title: makeover-musselburghs-david-macbeth-moir-statue
story: The Old Musselburgh Club, supported by the Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council, has reinstated the floodlighting and tidied up the statue of celebrated physician and writer David Macbeth Moir at the Mall.The project involved cutting back trees, repairing the floodlights as well as cleaning and repointing the main structure, and painting the railings.Club members paid tribute to Mike Foy and Glen Kane, of East Lothian Council, for their efforts with the pruning and electrical work involved at the monument which was erected in .Stuart Baxter, area partnership manager, and Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, supported by other area partnership members, also arranged for the base of the statue to be power washed, the main structure repointed and the surrounding railings painted at a cost of more than pound,. The area partnership allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to local projects.The Old Musselburgh Club marks the anniversary of the birth of Dr Macbeth Moir on the first Sunday in January each year with a church service and wreath-laying ceremony at the Mall.The  service will be held on Sunday, January , subject to restrictions as might apply in relation to Covid-.Born in the town in , Dr Macbeth Moir worked tirelessly as a doctor throughout his le and was Musselburghrsquos medical officer in  during the cholera epidemics which badly affected the local community.Club members are joined by descendants of his family Ian and Marion Moir from Edinburgh in remembrance of the man who was also a writer, adopting the Greek letter Delta as his pen name.Each year, a service in his memory takes place at a local church.Macbeth Moir had a family of , three of whom died under the age of four. A member of the Kirk Session at St Michaelrsquos Church, he was also a councillor. He was badly injured in accidents in  and again in , and his general health suffered. He died on July , , in Dumfries.He was a contributor of prose and verse to magazines, particularly to Blackwoodrsquos Magazine under his Delta pen name.There are several street names in the town which make reference to him, as well as the JD Wetherspoon pub The David Macbeth Moir.

title: new-signpost-celebrates-wallyfords-heritage
story: It points both walkers and cyclists to Prestongrange Mining Museum and the site of the Battle of Prestonpans, Queen Maryrsquos Mount at Carberry, the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Trail and Drt Path ndash some of which will feature in this yearrsquos East Lothian Online Heritage Festival.The signpost, located at the start of the Wallyford Industrial Estate road, was provided by Wallyford Community Council with funding from Musselburgh Area Partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council.The signpost cost pound, and its installation was pound.Alister Hadden, community council chairman, said: ldquoAs Wallyford continues to grow and expand, we thought it would be good to show residents who have come to make their home in the new housing estates some of our places of interest and rich heritage.ldquoThe signpost is also a little reminder to people who have lived in the village for longer.ldquoWallyford Community Council wishes to express its sincere thanks and appreciation to Musselburgh Area Partnership manager Stuart Baxter and chairman Iain Clark, along with the other members, for funding and supporting this project. Thanks also to Keith Scott and his East Lothian Council roads team for installing the sign for all to benefit from.ldquoWe are encouraged more to be out walking and cycling, and this will enable people to learn a little more about the history that surrounds us.The East Lothian Online Heritage Festival is held from August  to September .A spokesperson said: ldquoThis year we have decided to hold an online heritage festival in place of the traditional Archaeology  Local History Fortnight. It will be an exciting opportunity to celebrate East Lothianrsquos heritage in new ways, and to safely explore historic buildings and archaeological sites, without leaving home. We have got an exciting programme of over  events ndash from virtual guided tours, presentations and films to workshops, poetry, and music.For more information, visit www.johngraycentre.org about archaeology archaeolo gy-events east-lothian-online-heritage-festival

title: gullane-authors-new-book-satire-response-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It might sound rather familiar, but it is also the premise of Gullane author Charlie Laidlawrsquos latest book.Being Alert! was released earlier this month and follows in a long tradition of British satire, looking at how the Government has dealt with an existential threat that rapidly becomes a national crisis.Mr Laidlaw told the Courier: ldquoI think it is a book with a subject a lot of people will be writing about, looking at it from all dferent angles and the Governmentrsquos response to Covid- and whether it was appropriate or not.ldquoI think at some appropriate point the Government will be asked searching questions about its response.ldquoWhat I hope my book does is set out what those questions are from the point of view of ordinary people up and down the country who have been affected by Covid-, or had their lives ended by Covid-.Usually, publishing a book takes ldquomonths and months, with Mr Laidlaw, who is a marketing consultant, opting to self-publish his latest novel to ensure it was available.The -year-old said it had been ldquoa very dficult book to write as he attempted to strike the right balance between humour and anger on an emotive subject.Across the world, more than , people have died from coronavirus, with more than , deaths across Scotland linked to the virus.He said: ldquoI hope my book strikes a balance between humour, on a subject which is anything but funny, and anger, which I think a lot of people do feel.ldquoPutting those things together, I hope my book is part of a healing process as much as anything .Mr Laidlaw said a lot of people felt ldquohelpless or powerless throughout the coronavirus pandemic, with many questions unanswered.He felt there would come a time when those in power would be facing questions, such as why the country was not locked down sooner and why was there a lack of personal protective equipment , as well as how the country would react in the event of another pandemic.Mr Laidlaw has three previously published books ndash The Space Between Time, The Things We Learn When Wersquore Dead and Love Potions and Other Calamities ndash with a fth book set to be published in .

title: new-community-kitchen-set-tranent-help-feed-community
story: Farsquoside Community Kitchen will be operated by Duncan McBride and Joyce Thomson, who both cooked about , meals for local people during lockdown.Their work was initially part of the community resilience effort in Tranent, which was led by the townrsquos community council and overseen by its member Mike Falconer.Joyce started off delivering leaflets for the resilience team alongside her husband Andy.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods, which set up the emergency food provision in Farsquoside and is overlooked by the Pennypit Trust, said she was looking for a chef to cook hot meals and Duncan, who works at The Sheep Heid Inn in Duddingston, Edinburgh, offered his services.Duncan then approached Joyce and Andy, his long-term friends, and soon got them involved.They then spent the next few months making thousands of meals from their base in Tranentrsquos East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, where Joyce works behind the bar, and used its kitchens to prepare the meals.They would be in the bowling club about five or six days a week making about  meals a day for those in need.Joyce said: ldquoIt was hard work to start with, we were making - meals a day but are now down to about .The pair then decided it was a good idea to carry this work on and set up a community kitchen.It is hoped that the new community kitchen will be based in the bowling club, although the venue is still to be confirmed.Duncan and Joyce will continue to work alongside the Pennypit Trust until they can support themselves independently.It is hoped that Farsquoside Community Kitchen will be open and al by next month, initially with social distancing in place.It is also a charity, with Joyce currently awaiting confirmation of the charity number.Joyce said that the community kitchen was set up to ldquohelp our most at need community in supplying very low cost meals, ensuring people continued to get the same quality of food they had under the resilience group.There is a community kitchen service already in operation in Haddington and the one in Tranent will be run along the same lines, but Joyce said Tranentrsquos would instead be open every day.She said she wanted to be able to provide good-quality, low-cost food to as many people as possible of all ages and backgrounds.There will be dferent menus on offer, such as those for breakfast and lunch, so prices will y but remain low.Joyce said: ldquoWe want to target everybody and have as many things on the menu as we can but still try and keep it simple.As well as food, she hopes the community kitchen will allow people to meet up and socialise with others.Some of the plans currently in the works include a dementia-friendly session and working with schoolchildren through the school hub, with deliveries of food still taking place once a week.A website is also being set up.Joyce hopes that she and Duncan will be able to give up their jobs at some point in the future and direct all of their time and effort into the community kitchen.She said: ldquoIrsquom hoping this takes off really well and will be busy enough every day.ldquoWersquore willing to put every hour into making it a success.ldquoI feel the community needs some sort of help like this.She thanked people who had donated so far, including local resident and bowler Ian James, who has donated a total of pound.Joyce said: ldquoThe amount of friends that have given donations over this time is unbelievable. Anything we need, people come through again and again, itrsquos totally amazing.She added that the overwhelming amount of support so far might be linked to her charity walks that she does every August alongside Brian Forbes. The -mile-long walks have raised about pound, for ious charities since they first took place.For more information on Farsquoside Community Kitchen, email f.dcomkit@gmail, call   or search for Farsquoside Community Kitchenon Facebook.

title: golf-star-catriona-matthew-visits-east-lothian-foodbank
story: Matthew, from North Berwick, visited the foodbank, on Tranentrsquos Civic Square, on August , the week before the competition took place.She brought some donations with her, and foodbank volunteer Barbara Edgar showed her around the foodbank.Matthew then helped make up a foodbank parcel for two adults in a household.She, alongside all of the foodbank volunteers, wore a mask and gloves while putting the food parcel together.The visit came after the foodbank was selected as the competitionrsquos official charity for this year, something foodbank director Candace Higgins said she was ldquoabsolutely delighted about and ldquoblown away by.On her visit, Matthew said: ldquoTo visit East Lothian Foodbank has been great actually.ldquoItrsquos just amazing seeing the volunteers and just seeing the work they did.ldquoBarbara showed me around and we made up a food pack for a couple for three days.ldquoBarbara, I must say though that I was very good at putting the little extras in all the time, so I think our bags were a little bit fuller perhaps than normal. Itrsquos quite humbling to see all the work that they do.ldquoItrsquos been fascinating to come and just see all the hard work ndash itrsquos run by volunteers ndash just to see all the work that they have been doing, especially the last four, five months during the pandemic.On the foodbank being selected as the Ladies Scottish Openrsquos official charity this year, she said: ldquoI think itrsquos great that big events like that thatrsquos going to be filmed worldwide, players coming from all over the world, it supports a local charity.Candace added: ldquoThe generosity of [tournament sponsors] Aberdeen Standard Investments, Catriona Matthew and everyone involved in the Ladies Scottish Open means we can continue doing vital work for the people of East Lothian.ldquoThis not only means we can continue to provide emergencyfood parcels to those in need but it will also allow us to expand and develop our community work to get to the root cause of food poverty in the county.As part of being the official charity, pound was donated for every birdie, pound per eagle and pound, for a hole in one across the whole competition.In total, pound, was donated.In celebration, the foodbank has also been running a social media campaign in line with #FeelGoodFood month.It was running the lsquoFeel Good Food Cuprsquo to find out the publicrsquos favourite comfort food, with the final a battle between tomato soup and rice pudding, with rice pudding victorious.Players also discussed their own feel good foods and a video of their answers can be watched at youtube watch vORcgdXdThAEast Lothian Foodbank was established in  to meet the needs of rising food poverty in East Lothian.

title: second-set-plans-approved-former-dunbar-coastguard-station
story: When Dunbar Coastguard swapped Lamer Street for Spott Road Industrial Estate last year, its former base was left empty. Now, the building overlooking the townrsquos East Beach could become a new home or holiday let.Judy Oxley was given planning permission to change the property into holiday accommodation, with the existing roof to be removed, the wall heads raised by one metre and a new roof put in place. The proposals did not, however, win universal approval.The local authorityrsquos planning department received six letters of objection to the plans.Grounds for concern included there being no parking for the home, as well as how noise from the building would ldquonegatively impact on neighbouring residential properties.Supporting the plans was Dunbar Community Council, which was keen to see the proposals given the go-ahead in order to ldquoregenerate the building and prevent its decay.It marks the second time in just a few weeks that Ms Oxley has been given planning permission to breathe new le into the building.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officials had previously rejected a bid to turn the building into a bijou beachfront home. However, the local authorityrsquos Local Review Body overturned that decision on appeal when councillors said the proposal was better than leaving the building to fall into a state of disrepair.

title: coronavirus-womans-genius-face-mask-tip-stop-glasses-fogging
story: As we progress further through lockdown, the Scottish Government has made it a legal requirement to wear face coverings in more places ndash making the use of them a lot more widespread.But a number of Scots have been struggling to manage the masks ndash stating that it causes their glasses to steam or fog up.Thatrsquos where Nic Jam comes in.Faced with the same problems, Nic came up with her own solution ndash and decided to share it with the world on Facebook.So far, her handy tip has been shared almost , times, but not everyone agrees.She wrote: ldquoBespectacled peeps. I sewed a button on to my mask so my glasses can rest a bit further away from my face but not slip off.ldquoNo more fogging up or constant adjusting. Pass it on! Have made this post public to be shareable.In the picture shown, the button helps keep the glasses slightly further away ndash avoiding any steaming coming up from gaps in the mask.Some people loved the idea, including one Facebook user who said ldquoOh my god, this is such a good idea! I need to try this.Another added: ldquoIrsquom definitely going to get buttons at the weekend to try this.However not everyone was convinced.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in more indoor public places in Scotland.This video explains where you must wear one #Detailed guidance # https:t.co QmCaYPog pic YWJXeeHOne said: ldquoItrsquos a nice idea but could cause problems. Better option is to put tissue on the inside of the mask to stop the warm, moist air rising.Another added: ldquoGlasses are supposed to fit in a certain place so this isnrsquot great.What do you think  Will you be trying this advice  Let us know in the comments.

title: scottish-child-payment-can-apply-10-per-child-per-week
story: The Scottish Child Payment will provide pound per week, per child to eligible low-income families.Ms Campbell said development of the benefit had been delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic.She announced the timeframe for applications during an update to the Scottish Parliament on the Scottish Governmentrsquos efforts to tackle child poverty.Her report said: ldquoWe will deliver our new Scottish Child Payment for households with an eligible child under six ndash called lsquogame-changingrsquo when it comes to tackling child poverty and needed all the more now.When will applications begin Applications for the benefit will begin in November, with the first payments for eligible families to take place from February .Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website.How much is this The new benefit amounts to an additional pound per child every year.Ms Campbell said: ldquoTogether with the support already in place through Best Start Grant and Best Start Foods, this offers families on low incomes over pound of financial support by the time their first child turns six.Ms Campbell continued: ldquoImportantly, we have not placed arbitrary limits on the number of children who can be supported and will make up to pound available for second and subsequent children.What  was announced She also announced an additional pound. million to help parents find employment, including pound million for disabled parents.Updating MSPs on the progress against child poverty targets, she said that during the   period almost a quarter of Scottish children were living in poverty, a figure she described as ldquoabsolutely unacceptable.

title: b-q-john-lewis-wilko-smyths-toys-superstores-issue-product-recalls
story: Weve put together all the details on what each company are recalling - and what to do.What have BQ recalled BQ have issued a recall on Masterlite B-E lampholder converters.The recall statement reads: "There is a risk of electric shock resulting from direct contact with internal live parts which could occuryou attempt to replace an E lamp without first switching off the mains supply."The products were on sale in BQ from October  to March ."All batches sold are affected by this issue."The product affected is:If you have purchased any of these converters, contact theFreephone helpline for further information    between Monday and Thursday .am to pm, and on Fridays from .am - pm.The statement adds: "Masterlite apologise for any inconvenience caused and thank you for your cooperation."Please note that only the products detailed in this safety notice are affected. All other lights sold by Masterlite are unaffected."What have John Lewis recalled The company have issued a recall on their John Lewis  Partners Dual Purpose Pocket Spring Cotbed Mattress.The item affected contains the product code: .Thisrecall is for products sold between June  and June  from johnlewis.A statement by John Lewis said: "We have recently retested this mattress, and unfortunately it has failed a firmness test on the newborn side which means it does not comply with legal requirements."The other side has passed the test and is safe to use regardless of age."Therefore, we ask that with immediate effect, you rotate the mattress to use the  month+ side. This can be identied by unzipping the cover."Please contact us on    to discuss this and arrange a replacement and a refund."We will arrange for the collection and disposal of your existing mattress in a responsible way."We are obliged to ensure the mattress is not used any more, and does not find its way on to secondary markets."Were sorry for any inconvenience or disappointment this product recall may cause you."What have Wilko recalled Wilko have issued a product recall on their own brandSafari Buddies tambourine assorted toy.The items affected are:In a statement, Wilko said: "We have recently become aware of a potential safety issue with our Wilko Safari Buddies Tambourine."We have identied that in certain circumstances, the pins that secure the cymbals can become detached, leading to a potential safety issue."As a precautionary measure we are therefore advising customers that have purchased the tambourine with the above batch codes to stop using the product immediately, keep it away from children, andit to any store for a full refund."Nothing matters more to us than our customer safety soyoursquove purchased this product from us, pleaseit to any of our stores for a full refund of the purchase price."Please note that the recall only applies to the batches highlighted above."If you have any questions, please contact your local Wilko store or call the Wilko Customer Care Team free on:   ."We wish to thank you for your co-operation and apologise for any inconvenience."

title: gyms-pools-reopen-scotland-august-31---key-changes-need-know
story: The First Minister revealed they will open their doors from August  ndash brought forward from a previous estimated date of mid-September.But a number of things will change as we continue to live in the lsquonew normalrsquo, with Scottish Government officials setting out new guidance for customers and staff to follow.Herersquos what to expect on your :Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.

title: face-coverings-scotlands-schools-explained-guidance-say
story: The updated guidance comes off the back of new public health advice, including World Health Organisation guidelines.So who has to wear a mask  And is it mandatory Here, we detail out everything you need to know:Who should now wear coverings In secondary schools, adults and all pupils moving around the school, such as in corridors and communal areas, where physical distancing is dficult to maintain.However, like in shops and other indoor spaces where masks are mandatory, the Scottish Government accepts there will be some exceptions - including people with certain health conditions.When will this come into force The new guidance will apply from Monday, August .Will schools provide coverings Nicola Sturgeon said plans will be in place for schools to provide extra coverings, to ensure no-one goes without a covering who wants one.Concerns were raised over a lack of social distancing in schoolsWhat about on school transport The new guidance says that all children aged five and over should wear a face covering on dedicated school transport. This is now brought into line with the public transport guidance.What about primary school children With the exception of school buses as outlined above, the new guidance in schools only applies to secondary school pupils.Do they need to be worn in class While staff and students can continue to wear face coveringsthey wish to, they will not generally be necessary in the classroom.This is because there is greater scope for physical distancing and face coverings can have an impact on teaching.However it remains the case that where adults cannot keep m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period , face coverings should be wornCan a child be excluded for not wearing one It is expected that the guidance will state that pupils should not be excluded from schoolthey do not wish to wear a face covering.Can someone help my child with their covering Education Secretary John Swinney said:ldquoSchools will be asked to ensure children and young people have clear instructions on how to put on, remove, and store face coverings."Any staff member or pupil will still be able to wear a face covering when they wish to do so."John Swinney confirmed the new guidanceWhy is this being done Mr Swinney added:ldquoThere is increasing evidence that face coverings can provide some protection for the wearer as well as those around them."We also know that some pupils have found it very dficult to physically distance when moving around school, which could increase the risk of transmission of the virus."And on school transport, as on public transport, there can be mixing between dferent age groups."What  was said Mr Swinney said:ldquoWe want to continue to protect what we have achieved in suppressing the virus and re-opening schools, and to do the best for children in schools."Alongside this change to the wearing of face coverings, we need to reinforce the importance of maintaining high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene and physical title: angelina-jolie-interviewed-schoolgirl-bbc-newsround
story: Sofia Roper, an S student at North Berwick High School, was offered the opportunity to talk with the actress, and her -year-old co-star Brooklynn Prince, by BBC Newsround.Sofia, , said: ldquoIt was fun but it was also scary. title: coronavirus-maskne-seven-ways-look-skin-wearing-masks
story: However, people wearing face coverings every day have been noticing that they have started to break out in acne, rashes and skin irritations.Have you had more breakouts since you started wearing a mask We have spoken to Dermalogica skin care expert and beautician Ashley Richards to find out why this happens and how you can protect your skin.What is ldquomaskne Maskne occurs when sweat, oil and bacteria are trapped on your skin while wearing a mask, creating the perfect breeding ground for breakouts.What causes it Maskne is caused by friction, rubbing, and occlusion of the skin by outside forces.Wearing a mask can trap dirt, oil, swear and humidity around the skin.Friction and irritation from the mask pushes bacteria into the skin, which creates micro-tears, and allows the bacteria and dirt to enter the skin more easily.This will lead to blackheads and whiteheads along the bridge of your nose, cheeks and chin. Masks can trigger ious types of skin irritationsand redness .There isnrsquot a prevention for maskne, as we need to continue wearing our masks, but there are ways that you can help combat the issues.Skin Care routineIf you want to combat the impact of maskne then having a good skincare routine is essential.It is just as important to cleanse your skin before wearing a mask as it is to cleanse after wearing a mask.To help your skin heal, Ashley would recommend using a squalane or balm cleanser so help remove make-up, dirt and debris.However,you are experiencing chapped, irritated skin or suffer from sensitivity then a gel based cleanseradvised.Dermalogicarsquos UltraCalming Cleanser helps to calm and cool sensitised irritated skin.ExfoliatingExfoliating is key to clear clogged pores and remove dead skin cells which will help reduce the impact of maskne.There are thousands of dferent types of exfoliators available from chemical, physical and masks but it is always important to follow the recommended application and how often you should use the product.Over-exfoliating your skin can compromise your skins barrier , damage the skins capillaries and dehydrate the skin.Ingredients such as glycolic acid, lactic acid and salicylic acid are great exfoliating athelping fight breakouts.Spot treatmentsUsing targeted spot treatments with ingredients such as salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide will help remove dead skin cells and decongest pores.Hyaluronic AcidsHyaluronic acid can hold , times its weight in water - so it is like a magnet for moisture.Using hyaluronic acid regularly will leave the skin feeling super-soft, radiant and reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles.Hyaluronic acid has antibacterial properties meaning it will help soothe and protect chapped, irritated skin.FoundationsOpt for tinted moisturisers rather than a heavy foundation or go bare faced to help cause less clogging in your pores - but donrsquot forget your SPF!MoisturisersHeavier moisturisers will sit on the skin for longer due to the humidity of wearing the mask which can cause further clogging and irritation of the skin.However, donrsquot want to stop using a moisturiser all together as our skin still requires hydration and moisture.Instead try using a light and soothing moisturise such as Charlotte Tilburyrsquos Magic Cream light.Chapped SkinFor those suffering from chapped skin try using a physical barrier cream such as Dermalogicarsquos Barrier Repair.Barrier Repair shields against environmental pollution and helps forty sensitive skin with a damaged barrier.

title: housing-plan-musselburgh-poundland-poundstretcher-post-office-site
story: An outline plan has been drawn up for the land and building that houses Poundstretcher, Poundland and the Post Office, which is currently up for sale.Edinburgh-based Scarlett Land and Development is inviting offers for the ldquoprime location with ldquoconsiderable redevelopment potential on behalf of the owner, who has not been named.Situated on the corner of Dalrymple Loan and High Street, an outline plan for  residential properties plus two commercial units has been drawn up for the site, subject to planning permission.Scarlett Land and Development stated: ldquoThe site lies in the defined town centre, adjacent to the Musselburgh Conservation Area and in close proximity to listed buildings.ldquoPlanning permission will be required for any redevelopment proposal and, whilst not allocated for any specic use within the East Lothian Local Development Plan, it is likely that a mixed use development of ground floor commercial with residential use above will be acceptable, subject to a high-quality scheme respecting the setting of the listed buildings, the character and appearance of the adjacent conservation area and the scale of buildings in the surrounding area.Architects have drawn up an outline scheme comprising of  residential units plus two commercial units at ground level fronting High Street. The housing is listed as one, two and three-bedroom properties, plus two commercial units of  and  sq.m.A spokesperson for Poundland said: ldquoWe rent the store from the landlord and so the ownership is not really our concern. But we love being in Musselburgh and are proud to be part of the townrsquos retail community.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoThe premises where Musselburgh Post Office is based are up for sale. Poundstretcher is the company that operates this Post Office. We have not received any resignation at this stage, so it is business as usual at this Post Office.Poundstretcher had not responded at the time of going to press.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquolsquoAny business being put up for sale comes at a cost to the community, as with the loss of a local business comes a loss of jobs and services to the area.ldquoWhile we come out of the Covid- pandemic, we need businesses as we start to re-energise our economy. Though we also need more houses to be built locally, I would hope that these are not replacing valuable businesses locally ndash a decision which is permanent and negatively affects the lives of anyone employed there.ldquoI hope that suitable thought goes into this proposal and that the iniduals that this would affect are given the utmost consideration.ldquoAs always, I hope that the highest attention is given to the views of those who live in the community, as their opinions are what really matter in planning decisions.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said: ldquoDevelopment is needed but must be appropriate for a busy location and central site.Musselburgh Conservation Society said it would reserve its position until members saw what was being proposed.Musselburgh resident and Green campaigner Jason Rose, via social media, mooted the idea of the community owning the site and asked members of the public what they would like to see.One post stated: ldquoA proper covered market with independent fishmongers, grocers and butchers, plus other local producers and space for outdoor stalls too.ldquoWhat is needed is parking. No parking, limited shoppers, added a member of the public.Another said: ldquoSomething for the creative industry would be good. Small units at reasonable rents, photography studio with workshop space, sound recording studio, rehearsal spaces for bands musicians.One post added: ldquoCould be nice to have a proper supermarket right on High St again.ldquoMy granny was forever complaining that Tesco was too far and it is quite a walk.

story: The First Minister suggests some Scots have had trouble trying to book coronavirus tests over the weekend due to a "major spike" in demand, which resulted in technical issues.Butyou are experiencing symptoms, how do you get a test  Heres everything you need to know.If you think you are experiencing symptoms of coronavirus, you should take a test. title: 60-events-offer-east-lothian-online-heritage-festival
story: East Lothian Online Heritage Festival boasts events ranging from virtual guided tours and presentations to films and workshops.The festival, on until September , is running in place of the traditional Archaeology and Local History Fortnight, which has been postponed.Events include The Big Glassworks Dig at Port Seton on September  and . Digs will be broadcast live so everyone can follow any discoveries from the old glassworks as they are uncovered.Battlefield events commemorating the Battles of Dunbar, Pinkie Cleugh and Prestonpans, including live footage from the commemoration ceremonies, will take place, as well as online exhibitions and films related to the Year of Coast and Waters, using historic images and oral histories from the archives.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet spokesman for the environment, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted our archaeology service has developed this alternative way of celebrating East Lothianrsquos rich heritage and history.ldquoWith a vast array of historic buildings and sites to explore virtually through more than  events, Irsquod encourage people to participate.On Saturday, events include the chance to join the Salt of the Earth project for a day of celebration of the heritage of the Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Gosford areas.There is the chance to take a virtual walk around Tranentrsquos historic burgh boundary and a guided heritage walk over, under and around seven bridges over the Esk in Musselburgh.Also on Saturday, Graeme Cavers, from AOC Archaeology, will give a presentation about how LiDAR was used to map the archaeology of the Lammermuirs. A traditional skills festival looking at everything from stone carving and pottery to herb foraging and plaster casting takes place.A short film based on interviews with fishermen from Cockenzie and Port Seton will be shown, while there is also a chance to find out how to build your own lsquoTrace Italiennersquo fort.On Sunday, Nicola Wright will tell stories inspired by coast, water and archaeology, while a childrenrsquos workshop takes place in Amisfield Walled Garden, near Haddington. Liz Curtis shares stories behind the place names of East Lothian and there is a presentation about John Muirrsquos home in Dunbar.Monday starts with a look at the history of Dunbar, which is marking  years since the town was granted its charter.Gullane and Dirleton History Society hosts a virtual guided walk of the Gullane end of the old branch railway line.The following day, a film looking at the Cousland Smiddy is shown, while there is a slideshow of some of the historic re-enactment events that Catching the Past has been involved in.Historian David Affleck explores the history of Whittingehame Estate, while Kate Campbell has written a collection of poetry inspired by the area around Whiteadder Reservoir.On Wednesday, a short slideshow looks at the history of county ports and harbours and Courier columnist Tim Porteus tells three East Lothian tales.For more information, go to johngraycentre.org

title: whisky-tours-even-work-post-covid-world
story: The mind-blowing grandeur of Glen Coe, as you stand beneath those giant mountains and feel so very small.The view up the Royal Mile at Festival time ndash that mass of people, noise and colour, against a backdrop of the castle.There are some places to see in Scotland that are special. The lsquomust-seersquo jewels that should be on the wish list of every tourist and local alike ndash the ones that actually surpass expectations and leave a lasting impression once yoursquove seen them.And for lovers of whisky, there are more than a few of these places too ndash the distilleries whose images take pride of place on websites and in magazines and which inhabit the dreams of fans around the world.The lonely trio clinging on to the rocks of Islayrsquos southern shore, their white walls standing as stark protection against the sea ndash Ardbeg, Lagavulin, Laphroaig.The architectural masterpiece that is Macallan, just outside the village of Craigellachie on Speyside ndash only a couple of years old, but already a global icon.And the old walls of the Blair Athol distillery in Pitlochry, so consumed by ivy itrsquos asthe stems and not the stone are keeping the place upright.Irsquove been to Islay, and to Macallan ndash and both more than lived up to my imagination. But while Irsquove driven past Blair Athol so many times Irsquove lost count, Irsquove never actually been able to go and visit.So when an invitation popped up on my email ndash come and visit, and bring someone with you. I would normally have been delighted. Irsquod been planning to take my dad for a day out, and this would normally have been the perfect thing. I would normally have been excited at the prospect of us both actually seeing first-hand this lovely little distillery.But, letrsquos face it, I wouldnrsquot normally expect such an invitation to come in the middle of a pandemic, and I wouldnrsquot normally need to do an impromptu risk assessment before accepting.The Scotch whisky industry is worth upwards of pound billion to the UK economy and millions of tourists flock to distillery visitor centres every year, eager to touch base with one of the most popular drinks in the world. In recent years, the industry has enjoyed record growth ndash and all the signs were that  would be another bumper season.But then Covid struck, the country went into lockdown, and visitor centres closed their doors.However, since last month, when restrictions began to ease and Scottish tourism began to get back to work, the industry has slowly been welcoming visitors.The owner of Blair Athol, drinks giant Diageo, is in the middle of its own rolling programme of reopening. It began with the Pitlochry distillery in the last week of July and will go on throughout summer and well into the autumn.At this time of year, a place like Blair Athol would normally see hundreds of visitors every day, with tour parties of  or more being guided past the giant mash tuns ndash where ground malted barley, or grist, is mixed with hot water to extract the sugars that will give le to the whisky ndash and given a peek inside the washbacks ndash where this sugary broth, or wort, is mixed with yeast and left to ferment to create a strong lsquobeerrsquo ready for distillation.Dozens more would normally just drop in to buy a bottle in the shop, or to enjoy a drink at the Mash Tun ndash a whisky tasting bar thatrsquos open to the public.But lsquonormalrsquo was the last word on our minds as my dad and I drove through the depths of Perthshire on our way to Pitlochry.Wersquod had to book our slot, as drop-ins are no longer allowed, and been given the usual spiel about precautions, social distancing, sanitiser and the like, but Irsquod heard it all so often by now that it barely registered. Itrsquos become like the safety briefing on a holiday flightbefore take off.Irsquove been to a lot of distilleries before, and normally I love the atmosphere, the peaceful way these places ndash in reality some of Scotlandrsquos busiest industrial sites ndash go about their business, but I didnrsquot know what to expect this time round. Would the experience be ruined, like a trip to the shops or a pint down the pub Wersquod been told to bring our obligatory mask ndash and warned that our temperatures would be taken.Groan.So as we walked up to the door and announced ourselves, I steeled myself for some military-style regime of control and discipline.ldquoHello, come in! The tour is about to start. Can I ask you to put your wrist up to the censor so we can check your temperature That was it hellip a little box on the wall not much bigger than a light switch. I held up my wrist as instructed and waited.ldquoBeep! Temperature normal.My dad followed and as the tape across the entrance was pulled back we proceeded to put on our masks.ldquoOh, no, you wonrsquot need these in here.And what turned out to be one of the best tours Irsquove ever been on had begun.Yes, there was sanitiser everywhere, and wersquod been asked to maintain our distance and keep to the one-way system, but far from being a hindrance, these quiet measures seemed to fit in with the feel of the place, and did nothing to detract from the tour.There were only four of us on the tour, and the usually busy public areas were deserted, so it felt aswersquod been given secret, after-hours access to the distillery.It was aswe had the place to ourselves and Karen, our guide, was our accomplice as we sneaked from room to room, past the mash tuns and the washbacks, and into the still room. We stopped here as Karen explained the distilling process and, despite the insane heat of production, we stayed a little while extra to chat and take pictures. This personal touch was a real and unexpected treat.We carried on like this right through the tour ndash Karen passing on her prodigious knowledge, us chatting and stopping to admire the beauty of the distillery. No crowds, no rush.The final pleasure was when we were led into the Mash Tun bar to sample the whisky. It was like an exclusive tasting normally only reserved for the big-rollers and high-payers. I was driving, so after a quick snf of each dram ndash Blair Athol -year-old, Blair Athol Distillery Exclusive, Auchroisk -year-old, and Talisker Storm, in case yoursquore interested ndash I decanted them into the little sample bottles provided and saved them for later.Dad, on the other hand, loved every second of this private display, and after chatting a while more to our fellow guests and Karen ndash ldquostay as long as you like, she reassured us ndash we nipped off to take more photos and visit the distillery shop.The shop was the only place where masks were needed, but it didnrsquot stop us marvelling at the goodies on offer, and chatting some more to the staff who seemed to be relishing this newfound ability to escape from the timetable.Dad bought a bottle, of course ndash Talisker Storm ndash and as we said our goodbyes and took a few more pictures, I vowed to be back in more normal times.But then again, maybe I wonrsquot wait until then and instead book another secret visit when it feels aswe have the place to ourselves.Maybe this new normal has something going for it after all.# Andy Clark is author of the Dr@m whisky blog. To book your experience call   or email Blair.Athol@malts.For more information about Diageo visitor centres, go to www.malts en-gb visit-our-distilleries

title: cant-wait-visit-five-munros
story: With breath-taking views at the top, theres no wonder why adventure-seekers take to the climb for hours on end.But with almost  to pick from, it can be a dficult decision.Here, weve pulled together five Munros wed love to try:Braeriach, CairngormsThe Cairngorms are quite dferent to many of other Scottish mountain ranges. Although their summits are mostly rounded and sweeping, they combine to make a vast and wholly unique landscape.The mountains in the Cairngorms rise up out of the remnants of the ancient Caledonian pinewoods and are home to superb wildle and an array of dramatic corries. Braeriach is the third highest mountain in the British Isles and is protected by a long approach walk through a natural tree line.This Munro comes in at km and takes around - hours to complete.Braeriach, Aviemore, PH QTBraeriachBeinn Alligin, TorridonBeinn Alligin, meaning jewelled mountain, is one of three of the Torridon giants and well deserving of its name. This magnicent pair of munros has its own pinnacle ridge called the Horns of Alligin.Sitting on the seaward side of Torridon it has an unmatched viewpoint with glimpses of Skye and the sea to one side, and great peaks on the other side with the Horns providing a stunning foreground.The Munro is around km and takes around - hours.Beinn Alligin Torridon, Alligin, AchnasheenBuachaille Etive Mor, Glen CoeBuachaille Etive Mor is the head of Glen Coe and reigns supreme with its awe-inspiring pyramidal appearance. It is affectionately known by many climbers as the Bookie and, along with its twin Buachaille Etive Beag, are among the most photographed of the Scottish mountains and itrsquos easy to see why!This Munro is perfect for those who want a climb and some incredible views.It is around km and takes around - hours to complete.Aonach Eagach Ridge, A, Ballachulish PH HXLiathach, TorridonAnother of Torridonrsquos three mountains, Liathach is perhaps the finest of them all. Its higher Munro looks almost inaccessible from most directions and even the easiest ascent involves a bit of scrambling but itrsquos certainly worth the effort.Beyond this point the mountain becomes even more dramatic and offers the perfect path for thrill seekers to climb to the top. The hidden north side of the mountain is even more spectacular and is well worth exploring.Slightly longer than the other of Torridonrsquos mountains this walk is around .km and takes around - hours.Achnasheen, IV ETLiathachSgurr nan Gillean, SkyeMany regard Sgurr nan Gillean as being the finest peak on Skye and it is one of the more dficult on this list. Even the easiest ascent on the southeast ridge is a pretty tough scramble ndash the other two ridges venturing into the realm of rock climbing.It appears fairly dramatic from Sligachan but this actually conceals much of the mountainrsquos finest features and its only upon a closer visit to Coire a Bhasteir that the true scale and magnicence of the Pinnacle Ridge reveals this Munrorsquos true stature.This walk is around km and takes roughly  to  hours to complete.Skye, IV SW

title: gardening-10-bulbs-buy-now-add-zing-spring
story: You may still be enjoying the summer, butyou want a gorgeous display of spring bulbs, you need to start planting them soon.Narcissi, snowdrops, grape hyacinths, fritillarias and tulips all make great displays, and can be planted from late summer through to the end of autumnyou want a riot of colour in spring.:Gardening: Will my dahlias look their best So check out these favourites to plant this year for a fantastic spring display.... MUSCARI ARMENIACUM MOUNTAIN LADYA twist on the traditional grape hyacinth, Mountain Lady, which grows to just cm, has paler blue flower spikes that appear bicoloured as they burst from their white buds. Perfect for front of border spots, or in containers to brighten up patios from March to May. Plant plenty of them for the best display.. SCILLA LILIO-HYACINTHUSThe name of these pint-sized bulbs derives from the fact they are lily-like and hate getting dried out. Plant in early autumn, ideally in woodland situations where they will give you generous mounds of deep green foliage, from which emerge the dark stems holding purple-blue cones of flowers. Also available in white.. ANEMONE FULLSTAR BLUEOne of the latest introductions from the exquisite range of Israeli anemones, Fullstar Blue produces large, fully double blooms in the richest shade of mauve-blue. Plant the bulbs in autumn and overwinter them in a sheltered space for best results. When the weather warms in spring, theyll start to sprout and can then be transferred to patio pots or sunny borders where they will grow to around cm, flowering in April and May.. FRITILLARIA TWIN TOWERS TRIBUTENamed in remembrance of  , this stunning fritillaria will produce two stems per bulb, and looks wonderful planted in groups of threes, as standalone specimens or mixed with contrasting daffodils, like Narcissus Thalia, and tulips Negrita and Menton. Plant them deep, around cm, slightly on their side to prevent water entering the bulb, and add sharp sand or grit to the planting hole.. ALLIUM PING PONGAlliums are quite wonderful in all their ious forms, but some of the huge purple ones can seem a little ostentatious in the wrong setting. This lovely pure white iety with a ball-shaped flowerhead is much easier on the eye, a cooler specimen altogether, that will look good peppered among drts of ornamental grasses. It grows between -cm tall, flowering in June.. TULIP EYELASHThese unusual bulbs, new for this year, have white outer petals and a deep rich pinkish-purple fringe that provide an eye-catching burst of colour. Theyll grow to around cm, doing best in well-drained soil with some sunshine. The large, robust flowers bloom in May and make great cut flowers as well as a stunning outdoor display. Plant them in groups for maximum impact.. NARCISSUS LAURENS KOSTERIf you love scented narcissi, the Tazetta group is for you, and this elegant heirloom candidate has a lovely sweet fragrance. Planted en-masse, they are a beautul sight in spring. They may look delicate but are strong and hold well in wind and rain. Perfect for container planting or the garden border, you can mix them with contrasting spring bulbs like Tulips Orange Emperor and Paul Scherer.. GALANTHUS ELWESII MOUNT EVERESTSnowdrops are a sign of hope as we start to emerge from the depths of winter, the first tiny signs of le while the rest of us are still hibernating. Mount Everest is a bold new candidate, a large iety, growing to cm, with grey-green broad leaves. Its perfect for pollinating insects, great for naturalising and also good in pots. It flowers in February and makes a good winter corner with Anemone blanda and Iris reticulata, thriving in woodland with a bit of shade. You will need to plant a lot to create an initial impact, before theyve been allowed to naturalise.. IRIS GERMANICA MISSION RIDGENew from Suttons, but not exclusively, these bearded irises produce exotic blooms of snowy white and lilac-blue, but are not strictly bulbs. They grow from rhizomes, fleshy tubers planted on their sides near the soil surface. Growing up to cm, they look lovely in the classic cottage garden border, flowering firstly in late May andyoure lucky, will give you a second show in early autumn.. FRITILLARIA IMPERIALIS RED BEAUTYIf you want some rich, warm colour in spring, this statuesque culti, new for , will give you striking deep red flower bells in April and May, growing up to cm tall. It prefers free-draining humus-rich soil with added grit or organic matter for extra drainage. Plant it in sun or partial shade. Crown imperials, as fritillaria are also known, look great in the open garden or in groups of three in large tubs or pots.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why we are all going mad for the joys of gardening
story: In recent months, it seems our village has been bang on trend as ever. Across the UK, as headlines foretold the devastation lockdown would wreak on this seasonal trade ndash footage of acres of wilting plants was grim ndash cannier businesses immediately shted to online and telephone orders. And, as recent figures show, people responded enthusiastically. During that period, Britons spent around pound. billion on garden plants, materials and tools. Contrary to the stereotypical picture of a Mr McGregor retiree, footering around in his potting shed, it was millennials who spent most. Their investment was double that of the rest of us, with the - age group spending an average pound per person, compared with pound among others.Some of that might be explained by the urgent need for equipment to turn a rectangle of grass into a more imaginative space for all the family to enjoy. Irsquom long past their age but still so new to gardening that I recall those early months as a ceaseless outlay on shears, secateurs, spades, forks, trowels, rakes, sieves... I could go on. Hence the need for a shed, which was soon festooned with tools dangling from hooks, propped against walls and stacked on shelves. Think of an Italian deli, with hams and salamis overhead, and floor to ceiling storage. Replace the delicious aroma of cheeses, coffee beans and truffles with potting compost, muddied buckets and oil to keep blades moving, and you get the picture.There are professional horticulturalists where I live who are well under , but thatrsquos probably not surprising. Those who choose to live in the country are already keen on the outdoors, whatever their vintage. Yet there is something of a renaissance occurring in this generation, as interest in their own plot is sparked into le, whether itrsquos an allotment, balcony, or back yard.In response to what you might call a growing trend, Alan Titchmarsh has said that he hopes more young folk will be encouraged to pick up their trowels and dig up drives, to help protect the planet. ldquoItrsquos not just about going on marches, he says. ldquoBeing practical is a hugely underrated resource and skill.Those who have unexpectedly found themselves with time to devote to their patch have probably realised how enjoyable it is too. Being in the fresh air, surrounded by birds, and perhaps with children larking around, has shown how much pleasure can be had in maintaining your part of the world. At this stage of le, competition for peoplersquos spare time is usually ferocious, with the demands of socialising, keeping fit and raising a family. In the past, unless you were actively emulating the Good Le, choosing to spend the weekend planting drills of potatoes or deadheading roses was borderline eccentric.Being forced to spend so much time at home has clearly made people reassess their outdoor space, and consider its potential. Making their plot child-friendly has been a priority for some. But for those who dread the thought of a football landing on tender seedlings and new blooms, there should be no conflict between serious cultivation and youngsters ndash quite the opposite. The earlier children encounter flowers and trees and the wildle they attract, the better for all our futures. And the sooner they recognise the need to treat living things with respect ndash although some trampling and breakage is almost inevitable ndash the more they will understand not just how nature works, but the ways in which we can support it.Irsquove lost count of the number of people who have said how much they have relished this aspect of lockdown. Having nowhere  to go has allowed them to concentrate on matters horticultural, and take time to make decisions or try experiments they otherwise could not have attempted. Having many more unfilled free hours has its upsides, as one neighbour has discovered. When the pandemic took hold she turned her greenhouse into a hotbed of tomatoes and her flowerbeds into a lettuce patchwork, and has been feasting on salads all summer. As have her friends.Inevitably, once the world opens up again, some recent converts will lose interest and the weeds will take revenge. Yet I have no doubt that many will already be hooked. The secret that no gardener ever mentions is that it is addictive. Each tiny success gives confidence to try something more adventurous. Mistakes are inevitable, but so are accidental triumphs. The thrill of discovering strawberries or nasturtiums thriving where before was a bed of nettles, is inspiring. The sight of bees and birds hovering for nectar, seeds and grubs is like preparing a banquet and watching as guests pile their plates high. To be honest, environmental reasons for sustainable, eco-friendly gardening are all but forgotten in the joy it brings. The reason why benches in most well-tended grounds go largely unused is because therersquos always something clamouring for attention. To sit sipping a GT while an unpruned shrub stares at you reproachfully, or a juicy stick of rhubarb cries out to be picked, is almost impossible.In my own limited experience, trying to keep on top of it all ndash and never coming remotely close ndash is part of what it is about. An expert recently told me that a garden will take all the time you give it, and then some. Yet the depths of winter is the time to put your feet up . The rest of the year is for helping the green things around you put down sturdy roots. As millennials can confirm, it has a very stabilising, calming effect on us too.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.
